original: According to Campbell, the hero at first refuses the call to adventure, but a mentor appears who helps them and they decide to 'cross the threshold' and travel into the 'special world' where the adventure happens. The next stage consists of passing tests, fighting enemies and meeting friends as the hero prepares to face their biggest challenge. For Luke the mentor is, of course, Obi-Wan, the friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO and the enemy is Darth Vader inside the special world of the Death Star.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: According to Campbell, the hero first says no to the exciting journey, but then a helpful guide appears and assists them. The hero then decides to 'take the first step' and enter a new and 'special world' where the adventure takes place. The next part involves overcoming difficulties, battling opponents and meeting allies as the hero gets ready to face their greatest challenge. For Luke, the guide is Obi-Wan, the allies are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO, and the enemy is Darth Vader in the special world of the Death Star.
mistral-medium-3: According to Campbell, the hero first says no to the adventure, but then a mentor helps them. The hero then enters a new world where the adventure takes place. Next, the hero faces challenges, makes friends, and fights enemies to prepare for the biggest test. For Luke, the mentor is Obi-Wan, his friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO, and his enemy is Darth Vader in the special world of the Death Star.
gemma-3-27b-it:
Campbell says that heroes usually don’t want to start their adventure at first. But then, someone older and wiser – a mentor – helps them and encourages them to begin. This is when the hero enters a new and different world where the adventure takes place. 

In this new world, the hero has to prove themselves by completing difficult tasks, fighting bad guys, and making new friends. All of this prepares them for their biggest challenge. 

For example, in Star Wars, Obi-Wan Kenobi is the mentor who helps Luke Skywalker. Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO become Luke’s friends. And Darth Vader is the main enemy, who Luke faces inside the Death Star – which is the ‘special world’ in this story.

*(A **mentor** is someone who gives advice and helps another person, usually someone younger or less experienced.)*

The next stage is about passing tests, fighting enemies and meeting friends while the hero gets ready for the biggest challenge. For Luke, the mentor is Obi‑Wan, the friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO, and the enemy is Darth Vader, all inside the special world of the Death Star.

original: Underutilised items may seem useless to some, but could be an asset to others. With the advent of the internet, online communities have figured out a way to generate profit from the sharing of those underused assets. Using websites and social media groups that facilitate the buying and selling of second-hand goods, it is now easier than ever for peer-to-peer sharing activities to take place. And this is known as the sharing economy.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Some things that people do not use much may seem useless, but they can be valuable to others. The internet has made it possible for people to make money by sharing these unused things. Online groups and websites allow people to buy and sell second-hand items easily. This has made it simple for people to share things with each other, and this is called the sharing economy.

original: Around the 18th and 19th centuries two main ideas about dreams became popular. One was the idea that the things we see in our dreams represent things hidden from our conscious mind. Freud believed that if we understand what dreams are telling us, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. However, the other theory was the opposite. It said that dreams are just a collection of random activity in the brain while it's organising memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and put them into some sort of story.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: In the 18th and 19th centuries, two main ideas about dreams became well-known. One idea was that the things we see in our dreams mean something about our thoughts and feelings that we are not aware of. A man named Freud thought that if we understand our dreams, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. However, another idea was the opposite. It said that dreams are just a mix of random thoughts and images in our brain while it is sorting out memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random thoughts and images and create a story out of them.
mistral-medium-3:
In the 1700s and 1800s, two main ideas about dreams became well-known. The first idea was that dreams show things we don’t usually think about. Freud thought that if we understand our dreams, we can learn about our hidden feelings and the problems they create.

The second idea was very different. It said that dreams are just random thoughts and images from the brain while it sorts out memories from the day. When we wake up, we try to turn these random thoughts into a story that makes sense.
gemma-3-27b-it:
In the 1700s and 1800s, people started to have two main ideas about why we dream. 

One idea was that dreams show us things we don’t realise we’re thinking about – hidden feelings or problems. A famous doctor, Freud, thought that by understanding our dreams, we could understand these hidden feelings and why they bother us.

The other idea was different. It said that dreams aren’t important messages. Instead, they are just what happens when our brain is busy sorting out memories and things that happened during the day. When we wake up, we try to create a story to explain the strange images and feelings we had in our dream.
gpt-oss-120b:
In the 1700s and 1800s two main ideas about dreams became popular.  

The first idea said that the pictures we see in dreams stand for things that are hidden from our conscious mind (the part of our mind we are aware of). Freud thought that if we understand what dreams are telling us, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause.  

The second idea was the opposite. It said that dreams are just random activity in the brain while it is organising (arranging) memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and turn them into a story.
claude-sonnet-4: In the 1700s and 1800s, people had two main ideas about dreams. The first idea was that dreams show us things that are hidden in our minds - things we don't normally think about when we're awake. A man called Freud thought that if we can understand our dreams, we can understand our secret feelings and fix our problems. But the second idea was completely different. It said that dreams are just mixed-up brain activity that happens when our brain is organizing memories and things that happened during the day. When we wake up, we try to understand these mixed-up pictures and feelings and turn them into a story that makes sense.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: In the 18th and 19th centuries, two main ideas about dreams became popular. One idea was that the things we see in dreams stand for thoughts or feelings we are not aware of. Freud believed that by understanding our dreams, we can understand our hidden emotions and problems. The other idea was the opposite: dreams are just random brain activity while the brain sorts memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings by turning them into a story.
deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b: In the 18th and 19th centuries, two main ideas about dreams became popular. One idea was that the things we see in our dreams show things that are hidden from our mind when we are awake. Freud thought that if we understand our dreams, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. The other idea was different. It said that dreams are just random thoughts and feelings that happen while our brain is organizing memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and turn them into a story.
review:
**Model LL:**
Strengths: Maintains clear structure and explains concepts accessibly. Uses appropriate B1 vocabulary like "mix of random thoughts" and "sorting out memories."
Weaknesses: Adds unnecessary explanation "A man named Freud" which wasn't in the original. The phrase "create a story out of them" is slightly awkward.

**Model MI:**
Strengths: Converts centuries to numbers (1700s/1800s) which aids comprehension. Uses clear sequencing with "first idea" and "second idea." Vocabulary is appropriate for B1 level.
Weaknesses: Missing punctuation after "create" creates a run-on sentence. "Things we don't usually think about" is somewhat vague compared to the original meaning.

Weaknesses: Adds interpretive content not in the original ("why they bother us"). The explanation becomes wordier than necessary, potentially exceeding B1 complexity.

**Model GP:**

Weaknesses: The parenthetical explanations "(the part of our mind we are aware of)" and "(arranging)" may interrupt reading flow. Slightly more complex sentence structures.

**Model CL:**
Strengths: Uses very accessible language like "secret feelings" and "mixed-up brain activity." Explains concepts in simple, relatable terms.
Weaknesses: Changes meaning by adding "fix our problems" which wasn't in the original. "Mixed-up" appears repetitive. Some interpretive additions alter the original content.

**Model QW:**
Strengths: Maintains excellent fidelity to the original while simplifying appropriately. Clean, clear sentence structure. Preserves the formal tone while making it accessible.
Weaknesses: Very minimal - perhaps could have simplified "18th and 19th centuries" to numbers for better B1 comprehension.

**Model DE:**

Weaknesses: "Things that are hidden from our mind when we are awake" is slightly awkward phrasing. Could be more concise in some areas.

original: I'm a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I am in control of what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I was working from home, but I found it really hard to concentrate. There were just too many distractions around: housework that needed doing, another cup of tea, my family members wanting my attention for various things. So I started to go to a nearby café to work, but the Wi-Fi connection wasn't ideal and I found myself drinking too much coffee. In the end, I decided to rent a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers like myself. I liked getting dressed to go to work in the morning and being able to focus in an office environment.

original: Whether NASA can find the remaining middle-sized NEOs depends on getting the money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-metre space telescope which would use infrared light to locate asteroids. original: The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached influencers on social media who usually share posts of clothing and make-up that they recommend for people to buy. Some YouTube stars now encourage their viewers not to buy anything at all for periods as long as a year. Two friends in Canada spent a year working towards buying only food. For the first three months they learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes or things for the house. For the next stage, they gave up services, for example haircuts, eating out at restaurants or buying petrol for their cars. In one year, they'd saved $55,000.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: The 'buy nothing' trend is now popular among social media influencers who usually tell people what clothes and make-up to buy. Some famous YouTubers are now telling their followers not to buy anything for a long time, even up to a year. Two friends in Canada tried an experiment where they only bought food for a year. For the first three months, they learned to live without buying things like electronics, clothes, or home items. Then, they stopped using services like getting haircuts, eating out, or buying petrol for their cars. After a year, they had saved $55,000.

gpt-oss-120b:
The “buy nothing” trend is now also followed by social‑media influencers – people who often show clothing and make‑up they suggest you buy. Some YouTube stars now tell their viewers to stop buying anything for a long time, even up to a year.

Two friends in Canada tried this for one year. Their goal was to spend money only on food. In the first three months they learned how to live without buying electrical items, clothes, or other household things. After that they stopped using services – for example, they did not get haircuts, they did not eat in restaurants, and they did not buy petrol (fuel) for their cars.

After the whole year they had saved $55,000.

Some YouTube stars now tell their followers not to buy anything at all for long periods - sometimes for a whole year. Two friends in Canada spent a year trying to buy only food. For the first three months, they learned how to live without buying electronics, clothes or things for their home. In the next part, they stopped paying for services too - like haircuts, eating at restaurants or buying gas for their cars. In one year, they saved $55,000.

For the first three months, they learned to live without buying electronics, clothes, or household items. original: Religion is important to Pi. Though his family is Hindu, he is curious about other religions and he makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. To everyone's surprise, Pi declares himself to be simultaneously Hindu, Muslim and Christian. When his family and teachers ask him to choose just one religion, Pi refuses, saying 'I just want to love God'. From that moment, his family and teachers decide to let him make his own mind up about religion.

They are surprised by his answer, but from then on, they let Pi decide for himself what he believes about religion.

original: Some people think writing your dreams down can open your mind to lucid dreaming. Lucid dreams are dreams where you're not only aware you're dreaming but you can make decisions to affect the events of your dreams. So, maybe you can turn a nightmare into a safe-feeling dream, or you can direct the plot of your dream like a film director. Then, instead of just working out the meaning of your dreams, you'll be creating them, though you might want to continue having some dreams that allow your subconscious to tell you what's on your mind!
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Some people believe that writing down your dreams can help you have lucid dreams. A lucid dream is when you know you're dreaming and can control what happens in the dream. This means you can change a bad dream into a good one, or decide what happens next, like a director of a movie. Instead of just trying to understand your dreams, you can create them. However, it's still a good idea to have some dreams that can help you understand what's going on in your mind, without controlling them. This is because your subconscious, which is the part of your mind that thinks and feels without you realizing it, can tell you things you need to know.
mistral-medium-3: Some people believe that writing down your dreams can help you have lucid dreams. In a lucid dream, you know you are dreaming, and you can even control what happens. For example, you could change a scary dream into a happy one or decide what happens next, like directing a movie. This way, you’re not just trying to understand your dreams—you’re making them yourself. But it’s also good to let some dreams happen naturally, so your subconscious mind can show you what you’re really thinking or feeling!
gemma-3-27b-it:
Some people believe that writing down your dreams can help you have more control over them. This control is called “lucid dreaming”. It means you know you are dreaming while it’s happening, and you can even change things in your dream. 

For example, if you’re having a bad dream, you might be able to make it better. Or, you could decide what happens next in your dream, just like a director controls a movie. 

Instead of only trying to understand what your dreams mean, you can start to create them yourself! But it’s still good to have some normal dreams too – they can show you what you’re thinking and feeling without you even realising it.
gpt-oss-120b: Some people think that writing your dreams down can help you start lucid dreaming. Lucid dreaming means you know you are dreaming and you can decide what happens in the dream. So, you could change a scary dream into a safe‑feeling one, or you could guide the story of your dream like a movie director. Then, instead of only trying to understand the meaning of your dreams, you can actually create them. But you might still want some dreams that let your subconscious (the part of your mind that works without you thinking about it) show you what’s on your mind.
claude-sonnet-4: Some people think that if you write down your dreams, it can help you have lucid dreams. Lucid dreams are special dreams where you know you are dreaming while you are still asleep. In these dreams, you can control what happens and make choices about the story. For example, if you have a scary dream, you can change it into a nice, safe dream. Or you can control your dream like a movie director controls a film. This means that instead of just trying to understand what your dreams mean, you can actually create them yourself. But you might still want to have some normal dreams too, because they help your mind tell you what you are really thinking about!
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: Some people believe that writing down your dreams can help you have lucid dreams. Lucid dreams are dreams where you know you are dreaming, and you can even make choices that change what happens in the dream. For example, you could turn a scary dream into a calm one, or guide the dream like a movie director. This way, instead of just trying to understand your dreams, you are creating them. But you might still want to have some normal dreams, because they let your unconscious mind show you what you’re thinking or feeling.
deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b: Some people believe that writing down your dreams can help you have lucid dreams. Lucid dreams are dreams where you know you’re dreaming and can control what happens. For example, you could turn a scary dream into a safe one or direct the story like a movie director. Instead of just trying to understand your dreams, you could create them. However, it’s still good to let some dreams happen naturally to see what your subconscious is telling you.

Strengths: Provides clear explanation of lucid dreaming concept, includes helpful definition of subconscious, maintains all key ideas from original text.
Weaknesses: Slightly wordy and repetitive in places, adds explanatory content not present in original ("This is because your subconscious..."), making it longer than necessary for B1 level.

original: People might not realise they are part of the disposable clothing problem because they donate their unwanted clothes to charities. But charity shops can't sell all those unwanted clothes. 'Fast fashion' goes out of fashion as quickly as it came in and is often too poor quality to recycle; people don't want to buy it second-hand. Huge quantities end up being thrown away, and a lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent abroad, causing even more economic and environmental problems.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: People may not think they are contributing to the problem of disposable clothing because they give their unwanted clothes to charity. However, charity shops cannot sell all the clothes they receive. 'Fast fashion' quickly goes out of style and is often of such poor quality that it cannot be recycled; as a result, people do not want to buy it second-hand. Large amounts of clothing end up being discarded, and many items that charities cannot sell are sent to other countries, leading to additional economic and environmental issues.
mistral-medium-3: Many people don’t realise they are part of the problem with disposable clothing because they give their old clothes to charity. However, charity shops can’t sell all these clothes. "Fast fashion" (cheap, trendy clothes) quickly goes out of style and is often too low-quality to recycle. People don’t want to buy these clothes second-hand, so a lot of them are thrown away. Many unsold clothes are sent to other countries, which creates more economic and environmental problems.
gemma-3-27b-it: People may not think they are causing a problem with clothes when they give unwanted clothes to charity. But charity shops can’t sell all the clothes people donate. ‘Fast fashion’ – clothes that are made quickly and cheaply – become old-fashioned very fast and are often not good enough quality to reuse. People don’t want to buy them second-hand. So, a lot of these clothes are thrown away. Also, many clothes that charities can’t sell are sent to other countries, which causes more problems for their economies and the environment.
gpt-oss-120b: Many people do not realize they are part of the disposable‑clothing problem when they give their unwanted clothes to charity. Charity shops cannot sell all the clothes they receive. “Fast fashion” – cheap clothes made quickly – becomes out of style as fast as it became popular, and it is often too low‑quality to be recycled (turned into new material). Because of this, people do not want to buy these clothes second‑hand. A lot of the clothes are thrown away, and many of the items that charities cannot sell are sent to other countries, creating more economic (money‑related) and environmental (nature‑related) problems.
claude-sonnet-4: People might not know they are part of the throwaway clothing problem because they give their old clothes to charity shops. But charity shops can't sell all the clothes people give them. 'Fast fashion' (cheap clothes that follow the newest styles) becomes unfashionable very quickly and is often made so badly that it can't be recycled. People don't want to buy it in second-hand shops. Very large amounts of these clothes get thrown in the trash, and many clothes that charity shops can't sell are sent to other countries, which creates more money problems and damages the environment there too.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: People may not know they are part of the problem with throwaway clothes because they give their old clothes to charity. But charity shops cannot sell everything they receive. Fast fashion becomes outdated very quickly and is often too low quality to be reused or recycled. Many people don’t want to buy it second-hand. As a result, large amounts of clothing are thrown away. A lot of the clothes charities can’t sell are sent to other countries, which creates more economic and environmental problems.
deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b: People might not know they are part of the problem of disposable clothes because they give their unwanted clothes to charity. However, charity shops cannot sell all the clothes they receive. Fast fashion, which is cheap and trendy, goes out of style quickly and is often not good enough to be reused, so people don't want to buy it used. As a result, a lot of these clothes are thrown away, and clothes that charities can't sell are sent to other countries, leading to more economic and environmental issues.

original: Not content with one amazing trip, some of today's adventurers go from challenge to challenge. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on each continent, ridden a bike across Canada and run a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert in 45ºC heat. But perhaps her most remarkable journey was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and had to be rescued. Many of us would have given up at that point, but Meagan decided to carry on. She reached the South Pole forty days later, having pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food behind her through freezing conditions and ice storms.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Some adventurers today don't stop at just one exciting trip. They keep going from one challenge to the next. Meagan McGrath from Canada is a great example. She has climbed the highest mountain on each continent, cycled across Canada, and run a very long race in the Sahara Desert where it was extremely hot - 45ºC. But maybe her most amazing trip was when she went skiing to the South Pole. On the first day, she had a big accident - she fell into a glacier, which is a big river of ice, and had to be rescued. Most people would have stopped there, but Meagan didn't give up. She kept going and reached the South Pole 40 days later. She had to pull a special sled, called a sledge, with a tent and all her food through very cold weather and icy storms.
mistral-medium-3:
Some adventurers today don’t stop after one exciting trip—they keep looking for new challenges. Meagan McGrath from Canada has done many amazing things. She has climbed the tallest mountain on every continent, biked across Canada, and run a long race in the Sahara Desert where it was 45ºC. But her most impressive adventure was skiing to the South Pole.

On the first day, she fell into a glacier (a large, slow-moving river of ice) and had to be saved. Most people would have quit after that, but Meagan kept going. Forty days later, she reached the South Pole. She pulled a sledge (a small vehicle for snow) with her tent and all her food behind her through freezing weather and ice storms.
gemma-3-27b-it:
Some adventurers today don’t just do one exciting thing – they keep trying new challenges! Meagan McGrath from Canada is one of these people. She has climbed the tallest mountain on every continent (a continent is a large area of land, like Asia or Europe). She also cycled across Canada and ran a very long race in the Sahara Desert, even though it was extremely hot – 45ºC! 

But maybe her most impressive trip was skiing to the South Pole. On the very first day, she fell into a glacier (a large area of very thick ice that moves slowly) and needed help to get out. Most people would have stopped there, but Meagan continued. Forty days later, she arrived at the South Pole. She pulled all her things – a tent and food – on a sledge behind her, even though it was very cold and there were ice storms.
gpt-oss-120b: Not satisfied with just one great trip, many modern adventurers try many challenges. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on every continent, biked across Canada, and ran a long race in the Sahara Desert when the temperature was 45 °C. But her most amazing journey was a ski trip to the South Pole. On the first day she fell into a glacier – a huge, slow‑moving piece of ice – and had to be rescued. Many people would have stopped then, but Meagan kept going. She arrived at the South Pole forty days later, pulling a sled (a small cart) with a tent and all her food through very cold weather and ice storms.
claude-sonnet-4: Some people today love adventure and go from one challenge to another. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on each continent. She has also ridden a bike across Canada and run a long race in the Sahara Desert when it was 45ºC. But her most amazing trip was skiing to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and someone had to help her. Many people would have stopped, but Meagan continued. She reached the South Pole forty days later. She pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food behind her through very cold weather and ice storms.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: Some adventurers don’t stop after one big trip — they keep taking on new challenges. Meagan McGrath from Canada is one of them. She has climbed the tallest mountain on every continent, biked across Canada, and run a long race in the Sahara Desert where it was 45ºC. But maybe her most amazing trip was skiing to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and had to be saved. Many people would have quit then, but Meagan kept going. Forty days later, she reached the South Pole. She pulled a sledge with her tent and all her food through freezing weather and ice storms.
deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b: Some adventurers don't stop after one amazing trip. Meagan McGrath from Canada has done many incredible things. She has climbed the highest mountains on every continent, ridden a bike across Canada, and run a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert when it was extremely hot. However, her most amazing journey was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a crack in a glacier and had to be rescued. Most people would have given up at that point, but Meagan decided to keep going. After forty days, she reached the South Pole. She pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food through freezing weather and ice storms.

original: Blek le Rat started out painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. Nowadays, he tries to make people think about different social issues and problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities to encourage residents to think about the problem of homelessness.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Blek le Rat began by painting rats on walls in his hometown, Paris. Now, he tries to make people think about important social problems. He paints pictures of people who are homeless in big cities to encourage people who live there to think about the issue of homelessness.
mistral-medium-3: Blek le Rat began by painting pictures of rats on the walls of Paris, his hometown. Today, he wants people to think about important social problems. He paints images of homeless people in big cities to make residents aware of the issue of homelessness.
gemma-3-27b-it: Blek le Rat began by painting rats on walls in Paris. Now, his art tries to make people think about problems in society. He often paints pictures of people without homes in big cities. He does this to encourage people who live there to think about homelessness.
gpt-oss-120b: Blek le Rat began by painting pictures of rats on walls in his hometown, Paris. Today, he wants people to think about social issues – problems that affect many people in society. He paints images of homeless people in big cities so that residents will notice and consider the problem of homelessness.

original: In some areas, councils have tried to encourage artists not to paint graffiti randomly on walls by allowing them to work in designated areas. Taiwan is one such place and there are 'graffiti zones' where artists are free to paint and write on walls. In São Paulo in Brazil, the city council has even allowed some graffiti artists to paint on the city's subway trains.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: In some places, local governments have tried to stop artists from painting graffiti on walls without permission. They have done this by giving them special areas where they can paint and express themselves. For example, in Taiwan, there are special 'graffiti zones' where artists can paint and write on walls without any problems. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city council has even let some graffiti artists paint on the city's metro trains.
mistral-medium-3: In some places, local governments have tried to stop artists from painting graffiti on walls by giving them special areas to work in. Taiwan is one of these places, and it has "graffiti zones" where artists can paint and write on walls freely. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city even lets some graffiti artists paint on subway trains.
gemma-3-27b-it: In some places, local governments have tried to stop artists from painting graffiti in unwanted places. They do this by letting artists paint on walls in specific areas. Taiwan is an example of this, with special ‘graffiti zones’ where artists can paint freely. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city government has even allowed artists to paint on the subway trains.
gpt-oss-120b: In some places, local councils (the local government) try to stop artists from painting graffiti anywhere on walls. They do this by giving artists special areas where they are allowed to paint. Taiwan is one of these places; it has “graffiti zones” where artists can freely paint and write on walls. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city council even lets some graffiti artists paint on the city’s subway trains.
claude-sonnet-4: In some places, local governments have tried to help street artists by giving them special areas where they can paint instead of painting anywhere they want. Taiwan is one example - they have 'graffiti zones' where artists can paint and write on walls without getting in trouble. In São Paulo, a big city in Brazil, the city government has even let some graffiti artists paint on the subway trains.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: In some places, local governments have encouraged artists to stop painting graffiti on random walls by giving them special areas where they can paint freely. For example, in Taiwan, there are "graffiti zones" where artists can paint and write on walls without getting in trouble. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city government has even let some graffiti artists paint on subway trains.

For example, Taiwan has areas called 'graffiti zones' where artists can paint freely. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city government has let some artists paint graffiti on subway trains.
review:
**Model LL:**
Strengths: Maintains clear structure and includes all key information. Uses appropriate B1 vocabulary and explains concepts well with "without permission" and "without any problems."
Weaknesses: Changes "councils" to "local governments" and "subway" to "metro," altering specific terminology from the original. The phrase "stop artists from painting graffiti" misrepresents the original intent of "encourage artists not to paint randomly."

**Model MI:**
Strengths: Concise and clear presentation. Preserves the original meaning better with "giving them special areas to work in." Uses simple, appropriate vocabulary for B1 level.
Weaknesses: Also misinterprets the original as "stop artists from painting graffiti" rather than encouraging controlled graffiti. Omits some explanatory details that could help B1 learners.

**Model GE:**
Strengths: Uses "unwanted places" which better captures the concept of random placement. Maintains clear structure and appropriate vocabulary level.
Weaknesses: Still frames the approach as stopping rather than encouraging controlled graffiti. Changes "councils" to "local governments" and "city council" to "city government."

**Model GP:**
Strengths: Includes helpful clarification "(the local government)" for B1 learners. Preserves "councils" from the original text. Uses semicolon appropriately for sentence variety.
Weaknesses: Misrepresents the original meaning with "stop artists from painting graffiti anywhere," suggesting complete prohibition rather than redirection to designated areas.

**Model CL:**
Strengths: Best captures the supportive intent with "tried to help street artists." Adds helpful context "a big city in Brazil" and "without getting in trouble" for B1 comprehension.
Weaknesses: Changes "graffiti artists" to "street artists," altering the original terminology. Some additions may be unnecessary for the translation task.

**Model QW:**
Strengths: Most accurately preserves the original meaning with "encouraged artists to stop painting graffiti on random walls," maintaining the positive framing. Clear structure and appropriate vocabulary.
Weaknesses: Minor terminology changes from "councils" to "local governments."

**Model DE:**
Strengths: Very concise while maintaining essential information. Uses simple, clear language appropriate for B1 level.

original: Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to explore different locations. Her work is found on pavements, in empty factories and on abandoned cars. She likes the fact that most street art is temporary and will soon be removed by weather or cleaners from the city council. For her, this reflects how life is full of change with its cycle of endings and new beginnings.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Faith47 is an artist from Cape Town in South Africa. She creates large, colourful paintings of people and animals. She likes to work in different places and her art can be found on streets, in old factories, and on abandoned vehicles. What's interesting about her work is that it's often temporary - it can be washed away by rain or removed by city cleaners. Faith47 likes this because it reminds her that life is always changing, with things ending and new things starting.
mistral-medium-3: Faith47 is an artist from Cape Town, South Africa. She creates large, bright paintings of people and animals, often in different places. You can see her art on sidewalks, in old factories, and even on abandoned cars. She enjoys that street art doesn’t last forever—it can disappear because of weather or city workers cleaning it up. For her, this shows how life is always changing, with things ending and new things beginning.
gemma-3-27b-it:
Faith47 is an artist from Cape Town, South Africa. She creates large, bright paintings of people and animals, and she loves to paint in different places. You can find her art on sidewalks, in old, empty buildings, and even on cars that are no longer used. 

She likes that street art doesn’t last forever – the weather or city cleaning teams will usually remove it. She thinks this is a good thing, because it shows how life is always changing, with things ending and new things starting.
gpt-oss-120b: Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to work in many different places. Her art can be seen on sidewalks, in empty factories and on old cars. She likes that most street art does not stay forever; it is soon worn away by the weather or cleaned away by the city council (the local government). For her, this shows that life is always changing, with endings and new beginnings.
claude-sonnet-4: Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints large, bright pictures of people and animals and enjoys finding different places to paint. You can see her work on sidewalks, in old empty factories, and on cars that people don't use anymore. She likes that most street art doesn't last forever - rain, wind, or city workers will clean it away. For her, this shows how life is always changing, with things ending and new things starting.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: Faith47 is from Cape Town, South Africa. She paints large, colourful pictures of people and animals and enjoys working in different places. You can find her art on streets, in empty factories, and on old, unused cars. She likes that most street art does not last long — rain, wind, or city cleaners often remove it. For her, this shows how life is always changing, with things ending and new things beginning.
deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b: Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints large, colorful pictures of people and animals. She also likes to explore different places. Her art can be found on sidewalks, in empty factories, and on old, abandoned cars. She likes that most street art doesn’t last forever. It gets removed by the weather or city cleaners. This reminds her that life is always changing, with things ending and new things starting.
review:
**Model LL Analysis:**
Strengths: Maintains clear structure and adds helpful clarification ("artist") without changing meaning. Uses appropriate B1 vocabulary and explains the temporary nature clearly.
Weaknesses: Changes "pavements" to "streets" which is less precise, and "abandoned vehicles" is slightly more complex than the original "abandoned cars."

**Model MI Analysis:**
Strengths: Uses direct address ("You can see") which engages readers. Maintains original vocabulary level while being clear. Preserves "sidewalks" and "abandoned cars" accurately.
Weaknesses: "Bright" instead of "colourful" loses some descriptive richness. The phrase "often in different places" is awkwardly positioned.

**Model GE Analysis:**
Strengths: Provides helpful explanations ("cars that are no longer used," "old, empty buildings"). Uses engaging second person perspective. Clear logical flow.
Weaknesses: "Old, empty buildings" changes meaning from "empty factories." Some explanations may be unnecessarily verbose for B1 level.

**Model GP Analysis:**
Strengths: Stays very close to original text structure and vocabulary. Provides helpful parenthetical explanation of "city council." Maintains precise meaning throughout.
Weaknesses: Keeps more complex phrasing like "worn away by the weather" which could be simplified further for B1 level.

**Model CL Analysis:**
Strengths: Uses clear, simple language appropriate for B1. Good explanation of abandoned cars. Mentions specific weather elements ("rain, wind").
Weaknesses: "Cars that people don't use anymore" is wordy. "Old empty factories" loses the specific meaning of the original.

**Model QW Analysis:**
Strengths: Concise and clear language. Good use of em dash for emphasis. Maintains key concepts while simplifying appropriately.
Weaknesses: Changes "pavements/sidewalks" to just "streets" which is less specific. "Old, unused cars" is slightly awkward phrasing.

**Model DE Analysis:**

original: In her previous work environment, Gabriela was used to a high power distance culture where power and authority are respected and everyone has their rightful place. In such a culture, leaders make the big decisions and are not often challenged. Her Swedish team, however, were used to working in a low power distance culture where subordinates often work together with their bosses to find solutions and make decisions. Here, leaders act as coaches or mentors who encourage independent thought and expect to be challenged.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: In her old job, Gabriela was used to a work culture where people respected those in charge and everyone knew their position. In this kind of culture, the leaders made the important decisions and people rarely questioned them. However, her Swedish team was used to a different work culture where employees often worked together with their managers to find answers and make decisions. In this culture, leaders acted like guides who helped their team think independently and expected their team to share their opinions and disagree when necessary.
mistral-medium-3: In her old job, Gabriela worked in a culture where people respected authority and followed leaders without question. Leaders made decisions alone and were rarely challenged. However, her Swedish team worked differently. They were used to a culture where employees and bosses worked together to solve problems and make decisions. Leaders acted more like coaches, encouraging team members to think for themselves and even challenge ideas.
gemma-3-27b-it:
Gabriela used to work in a place where people clearly respected those in charge. Everyone knew their role, and leaders made most of the decisions – people didn’t usually question them. This is called a “high power distance” culture, meaning there’s a big difference in power between managers and employees.

However, her new team in Sweden is different. They are used to a “low power distance” culture. This means people work *with* their managers to solve problems and make decisions. Here, leaders help their team members develop their own ideas and *expect* people to share their opinions, even if they disagree. They act more like coaches or advisors than strict bosses.
gpt-oss-120b:
Gabriela had previously worked in a company where the hierarchy was strong – people accepted big differences in power and respected the boss’s authority. In that kind of workplace, the boss makes the important decisions and employees rarely question them.  

In her Swedish team, the hierarchy is much flatter. Workers and bosses often discuss problems together and share decisions. Here, the boss acts more like a coach or mentor, encourages people to think for themselves, and expects to be challenged.
claude-sonnet-4: In her old job, Gabriela was used to a workplace where bosses had a lot of power and workers always respected their authority. Everyone knew their position in the company. In this type of workplace, the leaders make all the important decisions and workers don't usually question them. However, her Swedish team was used to a very different workplace where workers and bosses work together as equals to solve problems and make decisions. In Sweden, leaders act like teachers or guides who want their workers to think for themselves and even disagree with them sometimes.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: In her old job, Gabriela was used to a culture where people respected authority and everyone knew their role. In this kind of workplace, leaders make important decisions and are rarely questioned. But her Swedish team was used to a different style, where employees and managers work together to solve problems and make choices. There, leaders act more like coaches who support independent thinking and expect team members to share their opinions, even if they disagree.
deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b: In her previous job, Gabriela worked in a culture where people respected authority a lot, and everyone knew their place. Leaders made important decisions, and employees rarely questioned them. Now, her Swedish team is used to a different culture where employees and bosses work together to solve problems and make decisions. Leaders here act more like coaches, encouraging team members to think independently and speak up with their ideas.
review:
**Model LL:**
Strengths: Maintains the core contrast between cultures effectively. Uses appropriate B1 vocabulary like "questioned," "guides," and "independently." Preserves the coaching/mentoring concept well.
Weaknesses: Loses the technical terms "high/low power distance" which may be important for workplace cultural understanding. The phrase "disagree when necessary" is slightly awkward.

**Model MI:**
Strengths: Clear, concise language appropriate for B1 level. Good contrast between "decisions alone" and "worked together." Maintains the coaching concept effectively.
Weaknesses: Omits the technical cultural terms. "Without question" and "rarely challenged" create some repetition in meaning. Loses some nuance about the cultural framework.

**Model GE:**
Strengths: Retains the technical terms "high/low power distance" with clear explanations. Uses formatting (*with*, *expect*) for emphasis. Provides comprehensive cultural context while remaining accessible.
Weaknesses: Slightly longer than other versions, which may challenge B1 readers. The explanation of technical terms adds complexity.

**Model GP:**
Strengths: Introduces "hierarchy" and "flatter" as useful workplace vocabulary. Good contrast between "strong hierarchy" and "flatter hierarchy." Clear progression from old to new workplace culture.
Weaknesses: "Flatter" may be challenging vocabulary for B1 level. Loses the specific cultural terminology that provides framework for understanding.

**Model CL:**
Strengths: Very clear language with "work together as equals" effectively conveying the concept. Good use of "teachers or guides" as relatable metaphors.
Weaknesses: "As equals" may oversimplify the low power distance concept - it's not about equality but about reduced power gaps. Loses technical cultural terms.

**Model QW:**
Strengths: Concise and clear. Good flow between contrasting cultures. Maintains the coaching concept and expectation of disagreement.
Weaknesses: Generic phrasing like "different style" lacks specificity. Omits the cultural framework terms that help categorize these workplace types.

**Model DE:**
Strengths: Simple, accessible language. Clear temporal contrast with "previous job" vs "now." Good use of "speak up with their ideas."
Weaknesses: Abrupt transition with "Now" when the Swedish team situation isn't necessarily current. Loses cultural terminology and some nuance about decision-making processes.

**Ranking:** ["Model_GE", "Model_GP", "Model_LL", "Model_QW", "Model_MI", "Model_CL", "Model_DE"]

original: When Gabriela became aware of the cultural differences between her and her team, she took the initiative to have an open conversation with them about their feelings about her leadership. Pleased to be asked for their thoughts, Gabriela's team openly expressed that they were not used to being told what to do. They enjoyed having more room for initiative and creative freedom. When she told her team exactly what she needed them to do, they felt that she didn't trust them to do their job well. They realised that Gabriela was taking it personally when they tried to challenge or make changes to her decisions, and were able to explain that it was how they'd always worked.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: When Gabriela noticed the cultural differences between her and her team, she decided to talk to them openly about how they felt about her leadership style. Her team was happy to share their thoughts and told her that they were not used to being given orders all the time. They liked having the freedom to make their own decisions and be creative. When Gabriela told them exactly what to do, they felt she didn't trust them to do their jobs properly. They explained that when they tried to suggest changes or question her decisions, she took it personally. However, they helped her understand that this was just their usual way of working, and it wasn't meant to criticize her.
mistral-medium-3: When Gabriela noticed the cultural differences between her and her team, she decided to talk openly with them about how they felt about her leadership. Her team was happy she asked for their opinions. They told her they weren’t used to being told exactly what to do. They liked having more freedom to make their own decisions and be creative. When Gabriela gave them clear instructions, they felt she didn’t trust them to do their jobs well. They also realized that Gabriela took it personally when they questioned or changed her decisions. They explained that this was just how they had always worked.
gemma-3-27b-it:
Gabriela noticed that there were differences in how she and her team thought about work, based on their cultures. So, she decided to talk to them openly about how they felt about her as a leader. 

The team were happy she asked for their opinions. They told her they weren’t used to being given strict instructions. They preferred to have more freedom to come up with their own ideas and ways of working. When Gabriela told them exactly what to do, they felt she didn’t believe in their abilities. 

The team also realised that Gabriela felt upset when they questioned her decisions or suggested different approaches. They explained that this was just their normal way of working – they weren’t trying to be disrespectful.
gpt-oss-120b: When Gabriela noticed that she and her team came from different cultures, she decided to talk openly with them about how they felt about her leadership. The team was happy that she asked for their opinions. They said they were not used to being told exactly what to do. They liked having space to take their own initiative and be creative. When Gabriela gave them detailed instructions, the team felt she did not trust them to do the job well. They understood that Gabriela felt hurt when they questioned or changed her decisions, and they explained that this was the way they had always worked.
claude-sonnet-4: When Gabriela noticed the cultural differences between her and her team, she decided to talk openly with them about how they felt about her leadership style. Her team was happy that she asked for their opinions. They told her honestly that they were not used to being given direct orders. They liked having more freedom to use their own ideas and be creative in their work. When Gabriela told her team exactly what to do, they felt that she didn't believe they could do their job well. The team understood that Gabriela felt hurt when they questioned her decisions or wanted to change them. They were able to explain that this was their normal way of working.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: When Gabriela noticed the cultural differences between her and her team, she decided to talk openly with them about how they felt about her leadership. Her team was happy she asked and shared honestly that they were not used to being told exactly what to do. They liked having space to take initiative and be creative. They explained that when Gabriela told them exactly how to do things, it made them feel she didn’t trust them to do their work well. They also realized that Gabriela took it personally when they questioned or changed her decisions, so they explained that this was just their normal way of working.
deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b: When Gabriela noticed cultural differences with her team, she decided to talk openly about how they felt about her leadership style. Her team was happy to share their thoughts. They said they weren't used to being told exactly what to do and preferred having more freedom to take initiative and be creative. When Gabriela gave specific instructions, they felt she didn't trust them. They realized she felt it was personal when they questioned or tried to change her decisions and explained that this was how they usually worked.
review:
**Model LL:**
Strengths: Captures the main narrative flow and includes key elements like cultural differences, open conversation, and team preferences. The language is accessible for B1 level.
Weaknesses: Adds interpretive elements not in the original ("given orders all the time," "wasn't meant to criticize her") and slightly shifts the meaning by suggesting the team helped Gabriela understand rather than simply explaining their perspective.

**Model MI:**
Strengths: Maintains close fidelity to the original content and structure. Uses appropriate B1-level vocabulary while preserving the key concepts of initiative, creative freedom, and trust issues.
Weaknesses: The phrase "questioned or changed her decisions" could be clearer, and some sentences feel slightly choppy in flow.

**Model GE:**
Strengths: Provides good contextual explanation ("differences in how she and her team thought about work, based on their cultures") and includes the respectfulness clarification. Language is well-suited for B1 level.
Weaknesses: Changes "creative freedom" to "ways of working," which loses some specificity. The phrase "didn't believe in their abilities" is an interpretation rather than direct translation.

**Model GP:**
Strengths: Accurately conveys the core message with appropriate simplification. Maintains the emotional aspect ("felt hurt") and includes the key explanation about normal working methods.
Weaknesses: "Came from different cultures" oversimplifies the concept of cultural differences in workplace context. Some nuance is lost in the condensation.

**Model CL:**
Strengths: Includes specific details like "direct orders" and maintains the emotional elements. The language level is appropriate and the flow is natural.
Weaknesses: Changes "trust them to do their job well" to "believe they could do their job well," which alters the nuance. The structure feels slightly repetitive.

**Model QW:**
Strengths: Maintains good balance between simplification and accuracy. Preserves the key concepts of initiative, creativity, and trust. The explanation of normal working methods is clear.
Weaknesses: Minor awkwardness in "they were not used to being told exactly what to do" repetition, and some sentence structures could flow better.

**Model DE:**
Strengths: Concise while maintaining essential information. Uses clear, direct language appropriate for B1 level.
Weaknesses: Omits some important details like the team being pleased to be asked and loses some of the nuanced explanation about their working style. The condensation sacrifices some clarity.

original: Os Gêmeos are identical twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything from tags to huge, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their work is often so big that they need cranes to help them work. In 2007, they covered the whole of a castle in Scotland with paint.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Os Gêmeos are twin brothers from São Paulo. They are artists who paint everything from small tags to large, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their paintings are often very big, so they need special machines like cranes to help them. In 2007, they even painted the entire outside of a castle in Scotland.
mistral-medium-3: Os Gêmeos are twin brothers from São Paulo who look exactly the same. They paint many things, from small drawings to very large, colorful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their paintings are often so big that they need special machines called cranes to help them. In 2007, they painted an entire castle in Scotland.
gemma-3-27b-it: Os Gêmeos are twin brothers from São Paulo, Brazil. They are famous for their paintings. They paint many different things, from small marks called “tags” to very large, colourful pictures of people on buildings. Their pictures are often huge, so they sometimes need to use cranes – large machines – to help them reach high places. In 2007, they painted an entire castle in Scotland!

qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: Os Gêmeos are twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint small tags and also large, colourful pictures of people on buildings. Their art is often so big that they need cranes to help them. In 2007, they painted an entire castle in Scotland.
deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b: Os Gêmeos are identical twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything from small tags to large, colorful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their work is often so big that they need cranes to help them paint. In 2007, they even painted the entire outside of a castle in Scotland.
review:

**Model CL:**

**Model QW:**

original: People have been painting and writing on walls throughout history. In prehistoric times, people in Africa and Europe used to paint pictures of animals and people in caves. Graffiti has been found on buildings at ancient sites in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In the Roman town of Pompeii, archaeologists have found numerous examples of graffiti written in Latin. These include religious, political and romantic messages, and even some magic spells!

original: Have you ever dreamt of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? If so, you're not alone. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across continents. Unlike the explorers of the past who used maps and compasses, today's adventurers travel with modern technology like GPS and satellite phones. Many adventurers are nature lovers who use their travels to help raise awareness about a range of environmental issues, while others are keen to help people in need and raise money for charities.

Now, people on adventures use modern technology like GPS, which helps them know where they are, and satellite phones, which allow them to make phone calls from anywhere. Many people who go on these adventures love nature and use their travels to inform people about problems with the environment. Others want to help people who are struggling and raise money for good causes, known as charities.

original: The first is DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Plans are scheduled to test DART on the moon of an asteroid called Didymos. 'Didymoon' is 150 metres wide, orbiting its 800-metre mother, and hopefully the impact of DART will knock it out of its orbit enough for Earth-based telescopes to pick up.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: The first test is called DART, which stands for Double Asteroid Redirection Test. This test will be done on a small moon that orbits a bigger asteroid called Didymos. The small moon, also known as 'Didymoon', is 150 metres wide and goes around the bigger asteroid, which is 800 metres wide. The plan is for DART to crash into 'Didymoon' and change its path enough that telescopes on Earth can notice the difference.
mistral-medium-3: The first project is called DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Scientists plan to test DART on a small moon orbiting an asteroid named Didymos. This moon, called "Didymoon," is 150 meters wide and circles a larger asteroid that is 800 meters wide. The goal is for DART to hit Didymoon and change its path just enough so that telescopes on Earth can see the difference.
gemma-3-27b-it:
One project is called DART, which stands for Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Scientists plan to test DART on a small moon that goes around a bigger asteroid called Didymos. This small moon, nicknamed ‘Didymoon’, is 150 metres across. The larger asteroid, Didymos, is 800 metres across. 

The idea is to hit Didymoon with DART. This impact should change Didymoon’s path around Didymos just a little bit. Scientists on Earth will then use telescopes to see if the impact worked and if Didymoon’s orbit has changed.

*(Asteroid: a rocky object that goes around the sun, like a small planet. Orbit: the path one object takes around another in space.)*
gpt-oss-120b: The first mission is DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test (a space mission that tries to change an asteroid’s path). The plan is to let DART hit the small moon of an asteroid named Didymos. This moon, called Didymoon, is about 150 metres wide and circles its larger partner, which is about 800 metres across. Scientists hope that the impact will move Didymoon enough for Earth‑based telescopes to notice.

Scientists hope that this change will be big enough to see from Earth using telescopes.

Weaknesses: Changes "plans are scheduled" to "test will be done," which loses some meaning. Uses "goes around" which is very basic but appropriate for the level.

**Model MI:**
Strengths: Maintains the scientific terminology while keeping language accessible. Uses "project" instead of just "test" which better reflects the original scope. Clear explanation of the size relationship between the asteroids.
Weaknesses: Uses "circles" and "hit" which are somewhat informal for a scientific context, though still appropriate for B1 level.

**Model GE:**
Strengths: Provides helpful definitions in parentheses for technical terms. Gives the most detailed explanation of the process and expected outcomes. Uses varied vocabulary while maintaining B1 accessibility.
Weaknesses: Significantly longer than the original text, adding information not present in the source. The added explanations, while helpful, change the text's scope and purpose.

**Model GP:**

Weaknesses: Changes "plans are scheduled to test" to "the plan is to let DART hit," which alters the meaning slightly. The phrase "let DART hit" sounds somewhat passive.

**Model CL:**
Strengths: Stays very close to the original structure and meaning. Uses simple, clear language appropriate for B1. Maintains the scientific context while being accessible.
Weaknesses: Uses "push it out" which is less precise than "knock it out of orbit." The phrase "normal path" is less technical than "orbit."

**Model QW:**
Strengths: Provides clear explanation of the process and expected outcome. Uses appropriate B1 vocabulary while maintaining scientific accuracy. Good flow and logical structure.
Weaknesses: Adds information about when DART hits that wasn't in the original. Changes the conditional "hopefully" to a more definitive statement about what "should" happen.

**Model DE:**
Strengths: Concise and clear translation that maintains the essential information. Uses appropriate vocabulary for B1 level. Stays close to the original meaning.
Weaknesses: Uses "they plan" instead of "plans are scheduled," which is less formal. Somewhat basic in its approach compared to other models.

original: The heroine of the story, a sixteen year old girl called Katniss Everdeen, has lost her father in a mining accident and has to provide food for her family. She hunts in the woods around District 12 with her friend Gale and becomes very skilful with a bow and arrow. When her younger sister, Prim, is chosen as one of the tributes, Katniss volunteers to go instead. The other tribute from District 12 is a boy named Peeta and Katniss soon finds herself in a complicated relationship with him.

original: Historically, more bridges were made of wood and were much more susceptible to fire. This was particularly true of old-fashioned train bridges, where the spark created by the steel wheels and steel tracks could sometimes cause a bridge to catch fire and burn to the ground.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: In the past, many bridges were made of wood and easily caught fire. This was especially true for old train bridges. When trains passed over these bridges, sparks were created by the metal wheels and tracks. Sometimes, these sparks would cause the wooden bridge to catch fire and burn completely.
mistral-medium-3: In the past, many bridges were made of wood and could easily catch fire. This was especially a problem for old train bridges. The sparks from the steel wheels and tracks could sometimes start a fire and burn the bridge completely.
gemma-3-27b-it:
In the past, many bridges were built with wood, and wood burns easily. This was especially a problem for older bridges used by trains. The trains had steel wheels on steel tracks, and sometimes this created sparks. These sparks could set the wooden bridges on fire and destroy them completely. 

**(Note: *susceptible* means easily affected by something. *catch fire* means to start burning.)**

original: It is impossible to know how street art will develop in the future but certain trends are emerging. While most street artists are young people who paint in their city or neighbourhood, more and more street artists are travelling and working around the globe. Other artists are using the internet to talk to each other and share photos of their work. Also, the art world is giving more recognition to street art as a legitimate art form. Although we don't know what will happen to street art in the future, we can be sure that it is here to stay!
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: It's impossible to predict how street art will change in the future, but some trends are becoming clear. Most street artists are young and work in their own city or area, but now more and more are travelling and creating art in different parts of the world. Some artists are also using the internet to communicate with each other and share pictures of their work. Additionally, the art world is starting to accept street art as a real and valid form of art. Even though we don't know what's next for street art, it's certain that it will continue to exist and be an important part of our culture.
mistral-medium-3: We don’t know exactly how street art will change in the future, but we can see some new trends. Most street artists are young people who paint in their own cities or neighborhoods. In addition, the art world is starting to accept street art as a real and important form of art. Even though we can’t predict the future of street art, one thing is clear—it’s not going away!

Also, people in the art world are starting to accept street art as a real type of art. 

Even though we don’t know what the future holds, we can be sure that street art will continue to exist!

review:

**Model CL:**

original: Suzanne Collines has always found news programmes of wars upsetting. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the US Air Force and he fought in Vietnam. It was a very frightening experience for her.

original: In a global survey conducted by PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC), more than 40,000 millennial (born between 1983 and 1993) and non-millennial responses were collected on the topics of workplace culture, communication and working styles, pay structure, career development, work–life balance, etc. In a separate global survey conducted by Deloitte, more than 10,000 millennials participated in a study about their perceptions of the threats and opportunities in the complex world of work.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Two big companies, PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) and Deloitte, did global surveys to learn about people's opinions on work. PwC collected over 40,000 responses from people of different ages about workplace culture, communication, pay, career development, and balancing work and personal life. Deloitte did a separate survey with over 10,000 younger people, born between 1983 and 1993, to understand their thoughts on the challenges and opportunities in the modern work world.
mistral-medium-3:
Two big companies, PwC and Deloitte, did surveys to learn about young workers, especially millennials (people born between 1983 and 1993).

PwC asked over 40,000 people—both millennials and others—about work topics like company culture, communication, pay, career growth, and work-life balance.

Deloitte also did a survey with more than 10,000 millennials. They asked about the challenges and opportunities in today’s complicated work world.
gemma-3-27b-it:

Deloitte also did a worldwide study, but only with over 10,000 millennials. This study looked at what millennials think are the biggest challenges and possibilities in today’s working world.

They answered questions about work culture, communication, working styles, pay, career development, work‑life balance, and similar topics. A separate worldwide survey by Deloitte included over 10,000 millennials and asked them about the risks and opportunities they see in today’s complex work world.
claude-sonnet-4: In a worldwide study by PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC), more than 40,000 people answered questions about work. Some were millennials (people born between 1983 and 1993) and some were not. They asked about workplace culture (how people behave and work together at their job), communication, how people like to work, how much they get paid, career development (how to get better jobs), and having time for both work and personal life. In another worldwide study by Deloitte, more than 10,000 millennials took part in research about what they think are the problems and good opportunities in today's complicated work world.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: PwC did a global survey with over 40,000 people, including millennials (born 1983–1993) and others, about workplace culture, communication, pay, career growth, work–life balance, and more. In another global survey by Deloitte, more than 10,000 millennials shared their thoughts on the challenges and opportunities they see in the changing world of work.

original: Erik Weihenmayer from the United States is a multi-adventurer. He's ridden a bike through the deserts of Morocco, kayaked through the Grand Canyon and climbed Everest. Amazingly, Erik has been blind since the age of 13. Apart from his travels, he tries to encourage people with disabilities to live active lives and takes groups of young blind people on climbing expeditions.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Erik Weihenmayer from the United States loves doing exciting outdoor activities. He has ridden a bike across the deserts of Morocco, gone kayaking through the Grand Canyon, and climbed Mount Everest. What's remarkable is that Erik lost his sight at the age of 13, which means he has been blind for most of his life. In addition to his adventures, Erik wants to inspire people with disabilities to be active and healthy. He takes groups of young blind people on climbing trips to show them that they can do challenging things too.

He also takes groups of young blind people on climbing trips.

original: Democratised online platforms are providing a chance for people to make a quick buck or two. To give an example, busy parents previously might not have bothered with setting up a stall at the local market or car boot sale to sell their children's old equipment, but with online marketplaces, parents are now able to sell on those hardly worn baby clothes that their children have outgrown and the expensive pushchairs and baby equipment they have invested in, so as to put some cash back into their pockets.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Websites where people can buy and sell things are giving everyone a chance to make some extra money. For example, busy parents might not have wanted to set up a stall at a local market to sell their kids' old things, but now they can use online selling platforms. They can sell things like baby clothes that have hardly been worn and expensive pushchairs that their kids have grown out of, and get some money back.
mistral-medium-3: Online platforms now make it easy for people to earn a little extra money. For example, busy parents might not have had time to sell their children's old things at a local market before. But now, with online marketplaces, they can sell clothes their kids have outgrown or expensive baby items they no longer need. This way, they can get some money back.
gemma-3-27b-it:
It’s now easier for people to earn a little extra money online. For example, parents who are busy might not have had time to sell things at a local market before. But now, with online marketplaces, they can easily sell things like clothes their children have grown out of, or baby equipment they don’t need anymore. This helps them get some money back from things they’ve already bought. 

*(Marketplaces are websites or apps where people can buy and sell things from each other.)*
gpt-oss-120b: Online platforms that anyone can use are giving people a chance to make a quick buck (extra money). For example, busy parents who used to avoid setting up a stall at the local market or a car‑boot sale can now sell their children’s almost‑new baby clothes, expensive pushchairs and other baby equipment on online marketplaces (websites where people buy and sell things). This lets them put some cash back into their pockets.
claude-sonnet-4: Online platforms that anyone can use are giving people a chance to make some extra money. For example, busy parents might not have wanted to set up a table at the local market or car boot sale (a type of outdoor market where people sell used things from their cars) to sell their children's old things. But now, with online marketplaces, parents can sell baby clothes that their children have grown out of and expensive pushchairs and baby equipment they bought. This way, they can get some money back.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: Online platforms are making it easier for people to earn some extra money quickly. original: Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days in the lifeboat. They live through hunger, illness and exhaustion. They endure violent storms and the burning heat of the Pacific sun, but somehow they survive. At times, Pi finds comfort in his three religions, but at other times he is overcome with loneliness and despair. Finally, the Mexican coast appears on the horizon and everything changes. It would be a shame to give away the ending, so you will have to read the book yourself to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker once land is in sight.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Pi and Richard Parker are in the lifeboat for 227 days. They face many difficulties like hunger, illness, and tiredness. They also go through very bad storms and extremely hot sun in the Pacific Ocean, but they manage to stay alive. Sometimes, Pi finds comfort in the three religions he believes in, but at other times he feels very lonely and sad. After a long time, they finally see the coast of Mexico in the distance, and everything starts to change. It's better if you don't know the ending, so you should read the book to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker when they see land.
mistral-medium-3: Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days on a small lifeboat. They suffer from hunger, sickness, and extreme tiredness. They face terrible storms and the strong heat of the sun, but they manage to stay alive. Sometimes, Pi feels better because of his three religions, but other times he feels very lonely and sad. Finally, they see the coast of Mexico, and everything changes. I won’t tell you the ending—you’ll have to read the book to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker when they reach land.
gemma-3-27b-it:
Pi and Richard Parker are together in a small boat for 227 days. It’s a very difficult time – they are often hungry, sick, and extremely tired. They experience strong, dangerous storms and very hot weather. Despite all these problems, they manage to stay alive. 

Sometimes, Pi feels better because of his religious beliefs. But at other times, he feels very sad and alone. After a long time, they finally see land – the coast of Mexico. When this happens, everything changes. I won’t tell you what happens next, you’ll have to read the book to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker when they reach land!
gpt-oss-120b: Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days together in a lifeboat. They have to deal with hunger, sickness and being very tired. They face strong storms and the hot Pacific sun, but they keep living. Sometimes Pi feels comfort from his three religions, and sometimes he feels very lonely and sad. At last, they see the Mexican coast on the horizon and everything changes. I won’t tell you the ending – you’ll have to read the book to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker when land appears.

They survive terrible storms and the very hot sun over the Pacific Ocean, but they manage to stay alive. Sometimes, Pi feels better because of his three religions, but other times he feels very alone and hopeless. Finally, they can see the coast of Mexico far away and everything changes. It would be wrong to tell you how the story ends, so you will have to read the book yourself to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker when they reach land.

They survive strong storms and the hot sun of the Pacific Ocean. Somehow, they stay alive. Sometimes, Pi feels comfort in his three religions, but other times he feels very lonely and hopeless. Then, one day, they see the coast of Mexico in the distance, and everything changes. It would be a pity to tell you how the story ends, so you need to read the book yourself to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker when they reach land.
