Now, The Hunger Games is a big movie made in Hollywood, and it’s also very successful. It earned 152.5 million dollars in its first weekend in North America! (North America includes countries like the USA and Canada).

Since then it has been translated into 26 languages and has sold millions of copies worldwide. It was also the first book for young readers to sell more than one million digital copies (electronic versions you can read on a computer or tablet). The story was later made into a big Hollywood movie, and the film is also a huge success. In its first weekend in North America the movie earned 152.5 million dollars.
claude-sonnet-4: The Hunger Games is a very popular book for teenagers and young adults. It was written by American writer Suzanne Collins. The Hunger Games was made into a big Hollywood movie and it was very successful too. In its first weekend, the movie made 152.5 million dollars just in North America!

Since it came out in 2008, it has been translated into 26 languages and sold millions of copies worldwide. It was also the first young readers' book to sell over a million digital copies. The book has been made into a big Hollywood movie, which is also very successful. In its first weekend in North America, it earned 152.5 million dollars!

Since it was published in 2008, it has been translated into 26 languages and sold millions of copies worldwide. It was the first young adult book to sell over a million e-copies. The Hunger Games is now a big Hollywood movie and is just as successful. It made $152.5 million in its first weekend in North America alone!
review:
**Model LL Analysis:**
Strengths: Clear and accessible language, good flow, uses "digital copies" which is appropriate for B1 level, includes "In fact" for emphasis which aids comprehension.
Weaknesses: Uses "impressive" which may be slightly advanced for B1 level.

**Model MI Analysis:**
Strengths: Uses italics for the title (proper formatting), clear sentence structure, maintains all key information from the original.
Weaknesses: Sentence structure is sometimes complex for B1 level, particularly the opening sentence with multiple clauses.

**Model GE Analysis:**
Strengths: Provides helpful explanations like "electronic books (e-books)" and "(North America includes countries like the USA and Canada)", uses simple vocabulary throughout.
Weaknesses: Adds explanatory content not in the original text, making it longer than necessary. The parenthetical explanation about North America may be too basic for the target audience.

**Model GP Analysis:**
Strengths: Provides clear explanation of digital copies with "(electronic versions you can read on a computer or tablet)", maintains good sentence variety, uses appropriate B1 vocabulary.
Weaknesses: Slightly wordy in places, the explanation of digital copies is quite long.

**Model CL Analysis:**
Strengths: Uses very simple vocabulary, provides explanation of e-books, breaks down complex ideas into digestible parts.
Weaknesses: Changes "author" to "writer" unnecessarily, the explanation "(e-books that you read on computers or special devices)" is somewhat awkward, uses "special devices" which is vague.

**Model QW Analysis:**
Strengths: Maintains good flow and readability, keeps sentences at appropriate length for B1 level, preserves all original information concisely.
Weaknesses: Uses "young readers' book" which changes the meaning slightly from "book for young readers."

original: Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. In one study, most happy people were found to have strong ties to friends and family and they made sure they spent time with them regularly. You also need at least one person who you discuss personal feelings with – called 'self-disclosure'. Just one person for a heart-to-heart is enough, together with a network of other relationships. It's not enough to have lots of friends just to do things with or chat to about music or football. That deeper connection is all-important. Some people need to learn how to listen effectively to others in order to develop stronger relationships.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Having good relationships is a big part of being happy. One study found that most happy people have close relationships with friends and family and they make time for them regularly. It's also important to have at least one person you can talk to about your personal feelings, which is called 'self-disclosure'. This means sharing your thoughts and feelings with someone you trust. You don't need a lot of friends, but you do need someone to have a deep conversation with, as well as other friends to socialize with. Just having friends to do things with or talk about hobbies is not enough. You need to feel a strong connection with someone. Some people need to learn how to listen carefully to others to build stronger relationships.

It’s not enough to have many friends just to do activities with or talk about simple things like music or sports. That deeper connection is what really matters. Some people need to learn how to listen well to others to build stronger relationships.

original: Psychologist and 'growth mindset' proponent Carol Dweck spoke of the plasticity of the brain and our ability to develop skills and talents that we might not have been good at to start with. Many of us tend to focus our praise on the end result and seemingly innate talents, e.g. 'You really have an eye for details' or 'You have a real talent for organising events'. However, research suggests that by focusing on the process of how things are done – praising effort, experimentation and problem-solving strategies – we can encourage the development of new skills and the continued honing of talents.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Psychologist Carol Dweck, who supports the idea of a 'growth mindset', talked about the brain's ability to change and develop new skills and talents that we are not born with. Many people praise others for their natural abilities, saying things like 'You're really good at paying attention to details' or 'You're a natural at organising events'. But research shows that if we praise the way people work and try to solve problems, rather than just their natural abilities, we can help them develop new skills and get even better at things they are already good at. This means praising their effort, their willingness to try new things, and their ability to find solutions to problems.
mistral-medium-3:
Psychologist Carol Dweck, who supports the idea of a "growth mindset," explains that our brains can change and grow. This means we can improve skills and talents, even if we weren’t good at them at first.

Many people praise natural abilities or final results, like saying, "You’re really good at noticing details" or "You’re great at organizing events." But studies show that it’s better to focus on the effort and process. For example, praising hard work, trying new things, and solving problems can help people develop new skills and get better at what they already do well.
gemma-3-27b-it:
Psychologist Carol Dweck, who is known for her work on ‘growth mindset’, says our brains can change and develop. This means we can get better at things we weren’t naturally good at. 

Often, we praise people for being clever or talented – for example, we might say “You’re really good at noticing details” or “You’re a natural at planning”. But research shows it’s better to praise *how* someone does something. 

If we praise effort, trying new things, and how people solve problems, we help them learn and improve. This encourages them to develop new skills and get even better at things they already enjoy. 

**(‘Growth mindset’ means believing that abilities can be developed through dedication and hard work.)**

But research shows that we should focus on how people do things instead. When we praise effort, trying new things, and ways of solving problems, we help people develop new skills and keep improving their talents.

This kind of praise helps people keep learning and improving their skills.

original: The rover analyses the air around it periodically, and in 2014 it found the air contained another of the most basic organic molecules and a key ingredient of natural gas: methane. One of the characteristics of methane is that it only survives a few hundred years. This means that something, somewhere on Mars, is replenishing the supply. According to NASA, Mars emits thousands of tons of methane at a time. The level of methane rises and falls at seasonal intervals in the year, almost as if the planet is breathing it.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: The rover regularly checks the air around it, and in 2014 it discovered methane in the air. Methane is a simple but important molecule found in natural gas. One interesting fact about methane is that it only lasts for a few hundred years. This means that something on Mars must be producing more methane to replace what is lost. NASA says that Mars releases large amounts of methane into the air at times. The amount of methane in the air increases and decreases at certain times of the year, similar to how a living thing breathes in and out.
mistral-medium-3: The rover checks the air around it regularly. In 2014, it discovered that the air contained methane, a simple organic molecule and a key part of natural gas. Methane does not last long—only a few hundred years—so something on Mars must be creating more of it. NASA says Mars releases thousands of tons of methane at once. The amount of methane goes up and down with the seasons, almost like the planet is breathing it in and out.
gemma-3-27b-it:

Methane doesn’t stay in the air for very long – usually only a few hundred years. This means something on Mars must be creating more of it. NASA says Mars releases a lot of methane, thousands of tons at a time. The amount of methane in the air changes with the seasons, going up and down, almost like the planet is breathing.

original: Early in her career, the psychologist Carol Dweck of Stanford University gave a group of ten-year-olds problems that were slightly too hard for them. One group reacted positively, said they loved challenge and understood that their abilities could be developed. She says they had a 'growth mindset' and are focused on what they can achieve in the future. But another group of children felt that their intelligence was being judged and they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset' and were unable to imagine improving. Some of these children said they might cheat in the future; others looked for someone who had done worse than them to boost their self-esteem.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: The psychologist Carol Dweck from Stanford University did an experiment with a group of ten-year-old children. She gave them problems that were a bit too difficult for them. Some of the children reacted well to this challenge. They said they enjoyed trying to solve the problems and believed they could get better with practice. Dweck calls this a 'growth mindset', which means they focus on what they can achieve in the future. On the other hand, another group of children felt that their intelligence was being tested and that they had failed. They had a 'fixed mindset', which means they didn't think they could improve. Some of these children even said they might cheat next time, while others looked for someone who did worse than them to feel better about themselves.
mistral-medium-3:
Early in her work, psychologist Carol Dweck from Stanford University gave some ten-year-old children problems that were a little too difficult for them. One group reacted well. They enjoyed the challenge and believed they could get better with practice. Dweck called this a "growth mindset," where people focus on what they can learn and achieve in the future.

But another group felt like they had failed and thought the test was judging their intelligence. They had a "fixed mindset," meaning they didn’t believe they could improve. Some of these children even said they might cheat next time, while others tried to feel better by finding someone who did worse than them.
gemma-3-27b-it:
When she started her work, psychologist Carol Dweck from Stanford University gave some ten-year-old children puzzles that were a little difficult. Some children were happy about the challenge. They believed they could get better at things if they tried. Dweck calls this a ‘growth mindset’ – meaning they think about what they can achieve in the future. 

However, other children reacted differently. They thought the puzzles were testing how clever they already were, and they felt bad when they couldn’t solve them. Dweck calls this a ‘fixed mindset’ – meaning they believed their abilities couldn’t be improved. Some of these children even said they might cheat next time. Others tried to feel better by finding someone who had done even worse than them. 

**(A ‘mindset’ is a set of beliefs about your abilities and qualities.)**
gpt-oss-120b:
Early in her career, psychologist Carol Dweck from Stanford University gave a group of ten‑year‑old children problems that were a little too hard for them.  

One group answered positively. They said they liked the challenge and believed they could get better with practice. This is called a **growth mindset** – the idea that you can improve your abilities over time.  

The other group felt that their intelligence was being judged and that they had failed. They had a **fixed mindset** – the belief that your abilities cannot change. These children could not picture getting better. Some said they might cheat in the future; others tried to find someone who did worse than them so they would feel better about themselves.

But another group of children felt that Dweck was testing how smart they were, and they thought they had failed. These children had a 'fixed mindset' - this means they believe their abilities cannot change or improve. They could not imagine getting better at things. Some of these children said they might cheat next time; others looked for someone who had done worse than them to feel better about themselves.

Some of these children said they might cheat later; others wanted to find someone who did worse, so they could feel better about themselves.

original: Horror films love uninhabited places. This could be an abandoned hospital, a scary empty house or a ghost town. There's something about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it's also that they are so quiet, which can be very scary too. Of course, abandoned places are also handy for horror film directors in that it's more believable that you will have no phone coverage there either.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Horror films often use empty places like old hospitals, scary houses or ghost towns. There's something frightening about places where nobody lives. We wonder what it was like when people lived there and why they left. These places are also very quiet, which can be scary. Another reason they're good for horror films is that it's easy to believe you wouldn't have phone signal there, making the situation even more terrifying.
mistral-medium-3: Horror movies often use empty, abandoned places like old hospitals, creepy houses, or ghost towns. These lonely spots make us wonder: What happened there? Why did people leave? The silence can also feel very scary. Plus, in these places, it’s easy to believe that your phone won’t work, which makes the situation even more frightening. That’s why filmmakers like to use them.
gemma-3-27b-it:
Horror movies often use places where no one lives anymore. These could be old, empty hospitals, frightening houses, or towns where people used to live but don’t now. There’s something strange about these lonely, empty places. We might wonder what life was like there before, and why people left. Also, the silence in these places can be really scary. 

It’s also useful for filmmakers that these places are often remote – it’s easy to imagine your phone wouldn’t work there, which makes the story more realistic.
gpt-oss-120b: Horror movies like places where nobody lives. This can be an old hospital, a scary empty house, or a ghost town (a town with no people). There is something about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it is also because they are very quiet, which can be scary too. Abandoned places (places that have been left empty) are useful for horror movie directors because it feels more real that there is no phone signal there.
claude-sonnet-4: Horror movies really like empty places where no people live. This could be an old hospital that nobody uses anymore, a frightening empty house, or a town where everyone has left. There's something special about quiet, empty places. What was life like when people lived there? Why did they go away? Maybe it's also because these places are so silent, and that can be very frightening too. Also, empty places are useful for horror movie makers because it makes sense that your mobile phone won't work there either.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: Horror films often use empty, forgotten places. This could be an old hospital, a creepy empty house, or a town with no people. There is something strange and interesting about these lonely places. What was life like there when people still lived there? Why did everyone leave? Maybe it’s also because they are so quiet — and silence can be very frightening. Also, these places are useful for film directors because it makes sense that you cannot get phone signal there.
deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b: Horror movies often use empty, scary places like old hospitals, empty houses, or ghost towns. There’s something interesting about places where no one lives anymore. You might wonder what life was like there before and why everyone left. These places are also very quiet, which can make them even scarier. Another good thing for horror movie directors is that it’s easy to believe there’s no phone signal in such places.
review:
**Model LL:**
Strengths: Maintains clear structure and logical flow. Successfully simplifies "uninhabited" to "empty places where nobody lives." Preserves the main ideas about wondering why people left and the lack of phone signal.
Weaknesses: Changes "love" to "often use" which loses some of the original's characterization. The phrase "making the situation even more terrifying" adds interpretation not present in the original.

**Model MI:**
Strengths: Uses accessible vocabulary like "creepy" instead of "scary." Maintains the questioning format effectively. Clear explanation of why filmmakers use these locations.
Weaknesses: "What happened there?" changes the original meaning from wondering about past life to implying something bad occurred. Adds "That's why filmmakers like to use them" which wasn't in the original.

**Model GE:**
Strengths: Provides clear explanations like "towns where people used to live but don't now" for ghost towns. Maintains the reflective tone about wondering what life was like. Uses "remote" appropriately for B1 level.
Weaknesses: "There's something strange" changes "something about" which was more neutral. Adds "which makes the story more realistic" - an interpretation not in the original.

**Model GP:**
Strengths: Includes helpful clarifications in parentheses like "(a town with no people)" and "(places that have been left empty)." Stays very close to the original structure and meaning. Maintains the questioning format exactly.
Weaknesses: The parenthetical explanations, while helpful, interrupt the flow. Some phrases remain quite close to the original complexity.

**Model CL:**
Strengths: Uses "really like" which captures the original's "love" better than other models. Clear explanations like "old hospital that nobody uses anymore." Good use of "silent" as a synonym for "quiet."
Weaknesses: "There's something special" changes the neutral tone to positive. "Mobile phone" is more specific than necessary. Adds "makes sense" which wasn't in the original.

**Model QW:**
Strengths: "Empty, forgotten places" is an effective simplification. Maintains the wondering questions well. Uses "strange and interesting" which captures some of the original's ambiguity.
Weaknesses: Adds "interesting" which wasn't implied in the original. "Cannot get phone signal" is slightly more complex than "no phone coverage."

**Model DE:**
Strengths: Clean, straightforward language appropriate for B1 level. Maintains key concepts without major additions. Good flow and readability.
Weaknesses: "There's something interesting" adds a positive connotation not in the original. "Another good thing" is an interpretation rather than translation. Loses some of the original's atmospheric quality.

original: No matter what kind of house it is, the basement is a scary place in horror films. That's usually where something is hiding or where the evil psychopath has hidden their tools. Basements are always dark and often damp. You can only reach them by a narrow staircase. And basements are always creepy, even when there isn't anything down there.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: In horror movies, basements are often frightening places. This is where something bad might be hiding or where a very bad person has hidden their dangerous things. **Model QW:**

original: Gary Collins, an off-duty policeman, was watching the London riots on TV. He immediately recognised several people and cut his holiday short to help with identification. He ended up spending six months going through the CCTV film and managed to identify 190 people, many from their eyes alone. His help was of decisive importance in the investigation. Even with 200,000 hours of footage, facial recognition software managed to identify just one person.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Gary Collins, a policeman who was not working at the time, was watching the London riots on TV. He quickly recognised several people he saw and decided to cut his holiday short to help the police identify them. He spent six months looking at CCTV footage and was able to identify 190 people, often just by looking at their eyes. His help was extremely important for the investigation. The police had a lot of footage to look at - 200,000 hours - but special software that recognises faces was only able to identify one person, making Collins' work even more valuable.

Even though there were 200,000 hours of video, the computer software for recognising faces could only identify one person.

original: Personally, I think it's fascinating to consider how we'll speed up our evolution as a species by augmenting our bodies. Imagine if you could implant a computer inside our brain! Soon we'll be able to do just that and enhance our mathematical ability, audiovisual perception and our memory, and this idea is only going to become more and more commonplace.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: I find it really interesting to think about how we can speed up the way humans develop as a species by improving our bodies. Imagine being able to put a computer chip inside our brain! Soon we will be able to do this and it will help us to be better at maths, to see and hear things more clearly, and to remember things more easily. This kind of idea will become more and more normal in the future.
mistral-medium-3: I find it really interesting to think about how we can make our bodies better to help humans develop faster. Imagine if we could put a computer inside our brains! Soon, this might be possible, and it could help us do math better, see and hear things more clearly, and remember things more easily. This idea is going to become more normal in the future.
gemma-3-27b-it:
I find it really interesting to think about how we might develop faster as humans by improving our bodies with technology. Just imagine being able to put a computer inside your brain! We might be able to do this soon, and it could make us better at things like maths, seeing and hearing, and remembering things. I think this idea will become more and more normal in the future. 

**(Augmenting means improving something by adding to it. Implant means to put something inside the body.)**
gpt-oss-120b: Personally, I find it amazing to think about how we can make our evolution faster by adding new parts to our bodies. Imagine putting a computer inside our brain! Soon we will be able to do that and improve our math skills, our ability to see and hear, and our memory. This idea will become more and more common.

This idea will become more and more normal in the future.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: I think it’s amazing to think about how we can speed up human evolution by upgrading our bodies. What if we could put a computer in our brain? Weaknesses: "Speed up the way humans develop" is slightly awkward phrasing. "See and hear things more clearly" adds interpretation not in the original.

Weaknesses: "Make our bodies better" is overly simplified and loses the technical meaning of "augmenting." Missing the personal opening "Personally."

original: It was a fascinating talk and the speaker really hit the nail on the head with a couple of things. Take parental influence, for instance. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing their homework when they witness their parents posting on social media while cooking the evening meal or waiting at a red light? She also made a valid point about people wanting to be in two or several places at once. So they switch back and forth between their real-life and online conversations. I see it all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They arrange to meet and then sit together in silence while each one engages in a different conversation online.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: The talk was really interesting and the speaker said some things that were absolutely right. For example, let's look at how parents influence their children. If parents are always checking their social media while doing other things, like cooking dinner or waiting for the traffic light to turn green, how can we expect teenagers not to do the same while doing their homework? The speaker also made a good point about people wanting to be in many places at the same time. This means they keep switching between talking to people in person and talking to people online. I see this happening a lot with my teenage daughter and her friends. They plan to meet up, but then they sit together in silence, each one chatting with someone else online.
mistral-medium-3:
The talk was very interesting, and the speaker made some great points. For example, she talked about how parents influence their children. If parents use their phones while cooking or driving, how can we expect teenagers not to use their phones while doing homework?

She also had a good point about people trying to do too many things at once. They switch between talking to people in real life and chatting online. I see this with my teenage daughter and her friends. They plan to meet, but then they sit together quietly while each one talks to different people online.
gemma-3-27b-it:
The talk was really interesting, and the speaker made some very good points. For example, she talked about how parents influence teenagers. It’s hard to ask teenagers not to use their phones for texting when they’re doing homework if they see their parents using social media all the time – even when they’re busy, like cooking or waiting for a traffic light. 

She also said something important about people wanting to do many things at once. People often switch between talking to people in person and talking online. I see this a lot with my daughter and her friends. They’ll make plans to meet up, but then they all sit quietly, each using their phones to chat with other people online instead of talking to each other.
gpt-oss-120b: It was an interesting talk and the speaker said exactly the right things about a few topics. For example, think about how parents affect their children. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing homework if they see their parents posting on social media while cooking dinner or waiting at a red light? She also pointed out that many people want to be in two or more places at the same time. So they keep moving between real‑life talks and online chats. I see this often with my teenage daughter and her friends. They plan to meet, sit together in silence, and each one talks on their phone or computer with different people online.
claude-sonnet-4: It was a really interesting talk and the speaker was completely right about a few things. Take how parents affect their children, for example. How can we expect teenagers not to send messages while doing their homework when they see their parents using Facebook or Instagram while cooking dinner or waiting at traffic lights? She also made a good point about people wanting to be in two or more places at the same time. So they keep changing between their real-life conversations and their online conversations. I see this happening all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They plan to meet up and then sit together without talking while each one has a different conversation online.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: It was an interesting talk, and the speaker correctly pointed out a few important things. For example, parents have a big influence. How can we expect teenagers not to text during homework when they see their parents using social media while cooking dinner or waiting at a red light? She also made a good point about people wanting to be in more than one place at the same time. So they keep switching between real-life conversations and online ones. I see this often with my teenage daughter and her friends. They meet up, but then sit together in silence, each one chatting with someone else online.
deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b: The talk was really interesting, and the speaker made some great points. One thing that stood out was about parents' influence. For example, how can we expect teenagers not to text while doing homework if they see their parents on social media while cooking or at a red light? The speaker also talked about how people want to be in multiple places at once. They switch between real-life conversations and online chats. I see this with my teenage daughter and her friends. They meet up but then sit in silence, each chatting online instead of talking to each other.
review:
**Model LL:**
Strengths: Provides clear explanations and maintains good flow. Successfully simplifies "hit the nail on the head" to "said some things that were absolutely right." Uses accessible vocabulary throughout.
Weaknesses: Slightly wordy in places ("checking their social media while doing other things"). The phrase "chatting with someone else online" could be clearer about it being different people.

**Model MI:**
Strengths: Concise and clear. Good simplification of complex ideas. Maintains the essential meaning effectively.
Weaknesses: Missing spacing after the period in "homework?She". Loses some nuance by simplifying "wanting to be in several places at once" to "trying to do too many things at once," which changes the meaning slightly.

**Model GE:**
Strengths: Comprehensive coverage of all main points. Clear explanations with good B1-level vocabulary. Effectively explains the contradiction between parent and teenager behavior.
Weaknesses: Somewhat lengthy, which may challenge B1 readers. The phrase "even when they're busy" adds unnecessary complexity.

**Model GP:**
Strengths: Maintains much of the original structure while simplifying language. Good use of "moving between" to explain the switching behavior.
Weaknesses: "Said exactly the right things" is an awkward translation of the idiom. "Real‑life talks" uses inconsistent punctuation (hyphen instead of standard dash).

**Model CL:**
Strengths: Natural-sounding language. Specific mention of "Facebook or Instagram" makes social media concrete for B1 learners. Good explanation of the behavioral contradiction.
Weaknesses: "Completely right" may be too strong. The specific social media platforms, while helpful, weren't in the original text.

**Model QW:**
Strengths: Concise and clear. Good balance between simplification and maintaining original meaning. Effective use of "correctly pointed out."
Weaknesses: "More than one place" is slightly less clear than other versions. Could benefit from more specific examples.

**Model DE:**
Strengths: Clear and well-structured. "One thing that stood out" is a good B1-level phrase. Maintains good flow between ideas.
Weaknesses: "Multiple places" might be challenging vocabulary for B1 level. The ending feels slightly abrupt compared to other versions.

original: As for news stories that make us think the world is an increasingly violent place, there is cause for some optimism too. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed more than 100,000 people. Today there are still civil wars, but countries are mostly co-existing more peacefully than in the past. However, terrorism has shot up in the last few years and, since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. Even for civilians, though, the statistics are not all bad. Although deaths are nine times more likely to be a result of violent crime than political conflict, the global murder rate fell slightly, from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: When we hear news about violence, it can seem like the world is becoming a more dangerous place. However, there are some positive trends to consider. After World War II, which ended in 1945, there were 30 big wars that resulted in a large number of deaths - over 100,000 people in each war. Nowadays, although there are still some civil wars, most countries are living together more peacefully than they used to. Unfortunately, terrorist attacks have increased in recent years. Also, since World War II, more civilians (ordinary people, not soldiers) have been killed in wars than soldiers. Despite this, the situation for civilians is not entirely negative. While it's true that people are more likely to die as a result of violent crime (like robbery or assault) than because of war or political conflict, the number of murders worldwide has actually decreased. In 2000, about 8 out of every 100,000 people were murdered, but by 2015, this number had fallen to around 5.3 per 100,000 people.
mistral-medium-3:
Some news stories make us think the world is becoming more violent, but there are also reasons to be hopeful. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars where over 100,000 people died. Today, there are still civil wars, but most countries live together more peacefully than before. However, terrorism has increased in recent years, and since World War II, wars have killed far more civilians than soldiers.

For civilians, the situation is not all bad. While people are nine times more likely to die from violent crime than from war, the global murder rate has actually gone down a little. In 2000, about 8 out of every 100,000 people were murdered, but by 2015, that number had dropped to about 5.3.
gemma-3-27b-it:
It can seem like the world is becoming more violent, but there is also some good news. After World War II, until 1990, there were 30 wars where over 100,000 people died in each one. Today, we still have conflicts within countries (called civil wars), but generally, countries are getting along better than before. 

However, there has been more terrorism recently. Also, since World War II, more ordinary people (civilians) have died in wars than soldiers. 

But even when we look at deaths of civilians, things aren’t completely negative. You are nine times more likely to die from a regular crime than from a war. In fact, the number of murders around the world has even gone down a little. It fell from 8 murders for every 100,000 people in 2000, to about 5.3 murders for every 100,000 people in 2015.
gpt-oss-120b:
News often makes us feel that the world is becoming more violent, but there are also reasons to be hopeful.  

From the end of World War II (the big war that finished in 1945) until 1990, there were 30 wars in which more than 100,000 people died.  

Today we still have civil wars (fights inside a country), but most countries live together more peacefully than before.  

In the last few years, terrorism (violent attacks by groups that want political change) has increased a lot.  

Since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians (people who are not soldiers) than soldiers.  

Even for civilians, the numbers are not all bad.  

A person is about nine times more likely to die from violent crime (like murder) than from political conflict (war).  

The worldwide murder rate has gone down a little: it was 8 deaths for every 100,000 people in the year 2000 and about 5.3 deaths per 100,000 people in 2015.

original: Wasfia has dedicated her life to supporting human rights and has witnessed numerous international humanitarian projects in her homeland to educate and train women and girls, but once too often they have been left with nothing when such projects have stopped running. Wasfia saw that Bangladesh needed to stand up for itself and so she brought together two of her passions, mountaineering and human rights, in order to try and change attitudes towards women in her country. She originally took up climbing while working on humanitarian campaigns in Tibet and Nepal, as in a coastal, primarily flat country like Bangladesh most people have never set eyes on a mountain. Her campaign seems to be doing the trick as fellow countrymen and women are sitting up and taking notice along with the rest of the world.

She started climbing while working on humanitarian projects in Tibet and Nepal. This was unusual because Bangladesh is a flat country with no mountains, and most people there had never seen a mountain before. Her campaign seems to be working, as people in her country and around the world are starting to pay attention and take notice.

original: The majority of people believe that developing countries are in a terrible situation: suffering from incredible poverty, governed by dictators and with little hope for any meaningful change. But, surprisingly, this is far from the truth. The reality is that a great transformation is occurring. Over the past 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their income and come out of poverty. Additionally, six million fewer children die every year from disease, millions more girls are in school and millions of people have access to clean water.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Most people think that developing countries are in a very bad situation: they are extremely poor, ruled by dictators, and have little chance of improvement. However, this is not true. In fact, a big change is happening. Over the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have earned more money and escaped poverty. Also, six million fewer children die from illnesses every year, more girls are going to school, and many people now have clean water.
mistral-medium-3: Most people think that developing countries are in a very bad situation: very poor, ruled by dictators, and with little hope for improvement. But this is not true. In fact, things are changing a lot. In the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have earned more money and are no longer poor. Also, six million fewer children die from diseases every year, millions more girls are going to school, and many more people now have clean water to drink.
gemma-3-27b-it: Most people think that poorer countries are in a very bad state – with a lot of poverty, ruled by unfair leaders, and with not much chance of things getting better. But, surprisingly, this isn’t really true. Actually, things are changing a lot for the better. In the last 20 years, over 700 million people have earned more money and escaped from poverty. Also, six million fewer children die each year from illnesses, many more girls are going to school, and millions of people now have clean water to drink.

Also, six million fewer children die each year from disease, many more girls are going to school, and many people now have clean water.

Also, six million fewer children die every year because of illness, millions more girls go to school, and millions of people can now get clean water to drink.

But surprisingly, this is not true. In fact, big changes are happening. In the last 20 years, over 700 million people have earned more money and moved out of poverty. Also, six million fewer children die each year from illness, many more girls now go to school, and millions of people can drink clean water.

review:
Looking at these B1-level translations, I'll analyze each model's strengths and weaknesses:

**Model LL**: Maintains clear structure and uses appropriate B1 vocabulary. The phrase "escaped poverty" works well. However, "extremely poor" might be slightly advanced for B1, and some sentences could be more simplified.

**Model MI**: Uses simple, accessible language throughout. The addition of "to drink" after "clean water" aids comprehension. The phrase "are no longer poor" is clearer than "escaped poverty." Maintains good flow while simplifying effectively.

**Model GE**: Shows good B1 adaptation by changing "developing countries" to "poorer countries" and "dictators" to "unfair leaders." Adds helpful clarification with "to drink." However, "state" instead of "situation" is less common at B1 level.

**Model GP**: Provides explicit explanation of "dictators" in parentheses, which is helpful for B1 learners. Retains "transformation" from the original. However, the parenthetical explanation disrupts sentence flow and "transformation" may be too advanced for B1.

**Model CL**: Uses very accessible language with "don't have enough money to live well" instead of "poverty" and "bad leaders" instead of "dictators." Clearly explains concepts. However, this approach sometimes makes sentences longer and more complex than necessary.

**Model QW**: Uses simple vocabulary and clear structure. "In very bad shape" is idiomatic and accessible. Maintains good sentence flow. Some word choices like "extreme poverty" could be simpler, but overall maintains clarity.

**Model DE**: Stays closest to the original text structure and vocabulary. Uses "developing countries" and "dictators" without simplification. While accurate, it doesn't adapt sufficiently for B1 level learners who may struggle with these terms.

**Ranking**: ["Model MI", "Model GE", "Model QW", "Model LL", "Model CL", "Model GP", "Model DE"]

original: In an attempt to inject some positivity into their feedback, many managers rely on sandwiching negative feedback between two positive comments. However, when feedback becomes such a routine, employees can start to perceive positive feedback as simply a form of sugarcoating the negatives, thus diminishing its value. Instead, positive feedback should not simply be seen as something to cushion the negative, but should be delivered so as to reinforce and encourage good performance.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Some managers try to give feedback in a positive way by saying something good, then something bad, and then something good again. However, when this happens too often, employees may think that the positive comments are just a way to make the negative comments easier to hear, and so they don't take the positive comments seriously. Instead, positive feedback should be given to make employees feel good about their work and to encourage them to keep doing well, not just to make the negative comments less painful.
mistral-medium-3:
Many managers try to make feedback more positive by putting negative comments between two positive ones. This is called the "sandwich method." However, if this method is used too often, employees may start to see the positive comments as just a way to hide the negative ones. This makes the positive feedback less meaningful.

Instead, positive feedback should not just be used to soften negative comments. It should be given to support and encourage good work. This way, employees will value it more.
gemma-3-27b-it: Many managers try to make feedback more positive by starting and ending with good comments, and putting the criticism in the middle – this is often called the “sandwich method”. However, if feedback is given this way too often, employees might think the positive comments aren’t sincere, and are just used to make the criticism seem softer. This can make the good comments less meaningful. Instead of using positive feedback to soften bad news, managers should give praise to encourage and support good work when it happens. This shows employees what they are doing well and helps them to continue performing at a high level.
gpt-oss-120b: Many managers try to add a positive tone to their feedback by putting a negative comment between two positive ones (this is called “sandwiching”). But when this is done a lot, employees may think the positive remarks are only a way to hide the criticism, so the praise loses its meaning. Instead, positive feedback should not just be used to soften the negative; it should be given to support and encourage good performance.
claude-sonnet-4: Many managers try to make negative feedback easier to hear by putting it between two positive comments. But when this becomes a normal pattern, employees start to think that positive comments are just a way to make the bad news sound better. This makes the positive feedback less meaningful. Instead, positive feedback shouldn't just be used to make negative feedback feel softer. It should be given to strengthen and encourage good work.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: Many managers try to make negative feedback more positive by putting it between two positive comments, like a sandwich. But when this happens too often, employees may start to see the positive comments as just a way to hide the negative ones. This makes the positive feedback less meaningful. Instead, positive feedback should not just be used to soften bad news. It should be given to truly support and encourage good work.
deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b: Many managers try to make feedback more positive by placing negative comments between two positive ones. However, when this becomes a regular practice, employees might start to see the positive feedback as just a way to soften the negative points, which makes it less meaningful. Instead, positive feedback should be used to support and encourage good work, not just to make the negative parts easier to hear.
review:
**Model LL:**
Strengths: Uses very simple vocabulary and sentence structures appropriate for B1 level. The explanation is clear and accessible.
Weaknesses: Oversimplifies the content significantly, losing some nuance from the original. The phrase "make employees feel good" is somewhat informal and doesn't capture the professional development aspect. Omits the concept of reinforcing good performance.

**Model MI:**
Strengths: Introduces the term "sandwich method" which adds useful vocabulary. Maintains good B1-level complexity while preserving most key concepts. Clear structure with logical flow.
Weaknesses: Minor formatting issue with spacing before "Instead." The explanation could be slightly more detailed about the consequences.

**Model GE:**
Strengths: Provides the most comprehensive explanation, including the term "sandwich method." Explains consequences clearly and offers concrete guidance. Maintains appropriate B1 vocabulary while being thorough.
Weaknesses: Slightly longer than necessary for B1 level, which might challenge some learners. Some phrases like "performing at a high level" could be simplified.

**Model GP:**
Strengths: Concise while maintaining key information. Uses appropriate B1 vocabulary. Includes the term "sandwiching" with explanation.
Weaknesses: Very brief, potentially missing some important details about implementation. Could benefit from more explanation of the positive effects.

**Model CL:**
Strengths: Clear, straightforward language appropriate for B1. Good explanation of the problem and solution. Natural flow between sentences.
Weaknesses: Doesn't mention the specific term for this feedback method. Could provide more detail about how to properly give positive feedback.

**Model QW:**
Strengths: Uses the sandwich metaphor effectively. Clear explanation of the problem. Appropriate vocabulary level for B1 learners.
Weaknesses: The phrase "truly support" adds unnecessary emphasis. Could be more specific about implementation strategies.

**Model DE:**
Strengths: Maintains professional tone while using accessible language. Clear cause-and-effect explanation. Good balance of simplicity and completeness.
Weaknesses: Doesn't provide the specific term for the feedback method. Could offer more guidance on proper implementation.

original: I'm a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Forget the movie image of a terrifying Terminator stamping on human skulls and think of what's happening right now: military machines like drones, gun turrets and sentry robots are already being used to kill with very little human input. The next step will be autonomous 'murderbots', following orders but ultimately deciding who to kill on their own. It seems clear to me that this would be completely unethical and dangerous for humanity. We need to be very cautious indeed about what we ask machines to do.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: I'm part of a group called the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. You might think of robots like the Terminator from the movies, but that's not what I'm talking about. Right now, machines like drones and robots that can shoot are being used in wars and they can kill with very little help from humans. The next step is to create robots that can decide who to kill on their own, without being told by a person. This is a big problem because it's not right to let machines make life or death decisions. It's also very dangerous for humans. We need to be very careful about what we ask machines to do.
mistral-medium-3: I’m part of a group called the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Don’t think about scary movie robots like the Terminator crushing skulls. Instead, think about what’s happening today: the military already uses machines like drones and automated guns that can kill with almost no human control. The next step could be robots that make their own decisions about who to kill. This seems very wrong and dangerous for people. We must be extremely careful about what tasks we give to machines.
gemma-3-27b-it:
I work with the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Don't think about robots from films – think about what’s happening today. The military is already using machines like drones and robot guns that can kill people with very little help from humans. The next step is to create robots that can decide for themselves who to kill, following orders but making the final choice. I believe this would be very wrong and dangerous for all of us. We need to be careful about giving machines too much power. 

**(Note: ‘drones’ are aircraft without a pilot, controlled remotely. ‘autonomous’ means able to work on its own without being controlled by humans.)**
gpt-oss-120b:
I am a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots.  
Don’t think of the scary movie robot that steps on people’s heads; look at what is happening now. Military machines such as drones, gun turrets and guard robots are already being used to kill, and they need only a little help from humans.  

The next step will be fully autonomous “murder‑bots”. “Autonomous” means they can act on their own. They would follow orders, but they would also decide by themselves who to kill.  

To me, this is completely wrong (unethical) and very dangerous for humanity. We must be extremely careful about what we ask machines to do.
claude-sonnet-4: I'm a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Don't think about scary movie robots like the Terminator crushing human heads. Think about what's happening today: military machines like drones (flying robots without pilots), gun towers and guard robots are already being used to kill people with very little human control. The next step will be robots that work completely alone, following orders but deciding who to kill by themselves. I think this would be completely wrong and dangerous for all humans. We need to be very careful about what we tell machines to do.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: I belong to the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Forget the scary movie robots crushing human skulls. Think about what’s happening now: military machines like drones, automatic guns, and guard robots are already being used to kill, with almost no human control. Soon, we could have fully independent "killer robots" that follow orders but choose their own targets. To me, this seems totally wrong and dangerous for humanity. We must be very careful about what we let machines do.
deepseek-r1-distill-llama-70b: I'm part of a campaign called Stop Killer Robots. Forget about the movie image of a terrifying Terminator crushing human skulls. What’s happening now is real: military machines like drones, gun turrets, and guard robots are already being used to kill with little human control. The next step is autonomous weapons, like ‘murderbots’, which will decide who to kill on their own. I believe this is completely unethical and dangerous for humanity. We must be very careful about what we ask machines to do.
review:
**Model LL:**
Strengths: Clear explanation of the concept, good use of simple vocabulary, effectively explains the progression from current to future technology. The phrase "life or death decisions" is accessible and impactful.
Weaknesses: Slightly wordy in places, uses "big problem" which is somewhat informal for the serious topic.

**Model MI:**
Strengths: Concise and direct, maintains the serious tone, good vocabulary choices for B1 level. Effectively contrasts movie fiction with reality.
Weaknesses: "Automated guns" is less precise than the original "gun turrets," loses some technical accuracy. Very brief treatment of the ethical concerns.

**Model GE:**
Strengths: Includes helpful definitions in parentheses, maintains good flow, explains technical terms clearly. The added notes section provides valuable vocabulary support.
Weaknesses: The explanatory notes break the text flow and may not be necessary for B1 readers. Some phrases could be simplified further.

**Model GP:**
Strengths: Provides clear definitions within the text ("Autonomous" means they can act on their own), maintains technical vocabulary with explanations, includes the term "murderbots" from the original.
Weaknesses: The parenthetical explanations interrupt reading flow, "steps on people's heads" is an awkward simplification of the original imagery.

**Model CL:**
Strengths: Integrates definitions smoothly within the text (drones explained as "flying robots without pilots"), clear progression of ideas, maintains appropriate vocabulary level.
Weaknesses: "Gun towers" is less accurate than "gun turrets," some definitions may be overly simplified.

**Model QW:**
Strengths: Natural flow, good vocabulary choices, maintains the urgency of the original message. "Choose their own targets" is clear and precise.
Weaknesses: "Automatic guns" loses the specificity of "gun turrets," "totally wrong" is somewhat informal for the context.

**Model DE:**
Strengths: Maintains much of the original structure and vocabulary, preserves the term "murderbots," keeps the serious tone intact.
Weaknesses: May be slightly above B1 level with terms like "autonomous weapons" and "unethical" without explanation, less vocabulary adaptation than other models.

**Ranking:** ["Model CL", "Model LL", "Model QW", "Model MI", "Model GP", "Model GE", "Model DE"]

original: Overall, more people are learning English than the other languages combined and English is spoken in the highest number of countries. However, Chinese has by far the greatest number of native speakers. There seems to be little correlation between how many native speakers there are of a language and the number of learners, but there is a stronger link between the number of learners and how many countries have speakers.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: More people are learning English than any other language. In fact, English is spoken in more countries than any other language. However, Chinese is the language with the most native speakers, meaning the most people speak it as their first language. It's interesting that the number of native speakers of a language doesn't seem to affect how many people learn it, but there is a connection between the number of learners and how many countries use the language.
mistral-medium-3: More people are learning English than all other languages together, and English is spoken in more countries than any other language. But Chinese has the most native speakers by far. There isn’t much connection between how many native speakers a language has and how many people learn it. However, there is a stronger connection between how many people learn a language and how many countries speak it.
gemma-3-27b-it: More people are learning English than all other languages put together, and it’s spoken in more countries than any other language. But, Chinese has the most people who speak it as their first language. It doesn’t seem to matter how many people grow up speaking a language – that doesn’t affect how many people want to learn it. However, there is a connection between how many people learn a language and how many countries have people who speak it.
gpt-oss-120b: Overall, more people are learning English than all the other languages together, and English is spoken in the most countries. Chinese still has the largest number of native speakers. There isn’t much connection between how many native speakers a language has and how many people learn it, but there is a clearer link between the number of learners and the number of countries where the language is spoken.

Weaknesses: Loses the comparative structure "than the other languages combined" by changing it to "than any other language," which alters the original meaning. Omits "by far" when describing Chinese native speakers, reducing emphasis.

**Model MI:**

Weaknesses: The phrase "There isn't much connection" could be clearer for B1 learners. Some sentences are quite direct without additional explanatory context.

Weaknesses: The phrase "It doesn't seem to matter" followed by "that doesn't affect" creates some redundancy. The final sentence becomes somewhat lengthy for B1 level.

Weaknesses: Uses "still has" which adds an implication not present in the original. The structure closely mirrors the original without much simplification.

**Model CL:**
Strengths: Uses simple present tense consistently. Maintains the comparative structure and key information. The vocabulary is accessible for B1 learners.
Weaknesses: Changes "are learning" to "learn," losing the ongoing aspect. The repetitive use of "But" at the beginning of sentences creates monotonous structure.

**Model QW:**

Weaknesses: The contrast marker usage could be more varied. Some sentences remain quite complex for B1 level.

**Model DE:**

Weaknesses: Omits "by far" when describing Chinese native speakers. The phrase "how many countries use the language" is less precise than the original meaning about countries having speakers.

original: Your manager stops you and says she needs to have a word about your performance in the recent project. You worry about it all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong. When you step into her office on Monday morning she begins by praising you for the good work you've done on the project, and you wonder if this is the obligatory praise that starts off the typical 'feedback sandwich'. You know how the feedback sandwich goes: say something nice, say what you really want to say, say something nice again.

You wonder if this is just a polite comment before she tells you what's really on her mind. You know how this kind of conversation usually goes: your boss says something positive, then tells you what you did wrong, and finally says something positive again. This is sometimes called a "feedback sandwich".

original: A fast-paced, foot-tapping rock album, Born in the USA's lyrics nevertheless carry emotional weight. Behind the catchy rock melodies that drive these powerhouse classics are stories of the dark side of the American dream. Many tracks deal with the struggles of hard-working ordinary people and the bitterness and anger they feel as life doesn't bring them riches or glory. The song Glory Days, for example, is about people in a small town looking back at when they were young and had the world at their feet while Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life is ruined when he loses his job. It's not hard to imagine that the artist is channelling real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn't become a star. The album will leave you in no doubt of the unique and extraordinary talent of the Boss.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Born in the USA is a high-energy rock album with catchy melodies that make you want to move your feet. But despite its upbeat sound, the lyrics deal with serious and emotional topics. The songs tell stories about the struggles of ordinary people who work hard but don't achieve their dreams of wealth and success. They feel bitter and angry about their lives. For example, the song Glory Days is about people looking back at their youthful days when they had big hopes and dreams, while Downbound Train is about a young man whose life falls apart when he loses his job. It's clear that the artist, known as the Boss, is writing about real people and experiences that he knows well. The album shows off his unique and amazing talent, leaving no doubt about his skill as a musician.
mistral-medium-3:
"Born in the USA" is a lively rock album with fast, exciting music. But the words in the songs are deep and emotional. Behind the catchy tunes, the songs tell stories about the difficult side of the American dream. Many songs talk about the problems of regular people who work hard but never get rich or famous. They feel angry and disappointed because life doesn’t give them what they hoped for.

For example, the song "Glory Days" is about people in a small town remembering their youth when life seemed full of possibilities. "Downbound Train" tells the story of a young man whose life falls apart after he loses his job. It feels like the singer is writing about real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn’t become famous.

The album shows just how talented the artist, known as "the Boss," really is.

Many songs are about the problems faced by normal, working people. They express the disappointment and anger people feel when life doesn’t go as planned and they don’t become rich or famous. For example, “Glory Days” is about people in a small town remembering their youth and lost opportunities. “Downbound Train” tells the story of a young man whose life is destroyed after he loses his job. 

You can easily believe the singer, known as “The Boss”, is singing about people he knew and imagining his own life if he hadn’t become a successful musician. This album clearly shows how talented and special he is.

The song *Glory Days*, for example, is about people in a small town remembering when they were young and felt they could have anything, while *Downbound Train* tells the story of a young man whose life is ruined after he loses his job. It is easy to think that the artist is using real people he knew and the life he might have had if he had not become a star. The album shows clearly the unique and extraordinary talent of the Boss.

The song Glory Days, for example, is about people in a small town who remember when they were young and felt like anything was possible. Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life falls apart when he loses his job. You can easily imagine that the singer is thinking about real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn't become famous. The album clearly shows the amazing talent of the Boss (Bruce Springsteen's nickname).

For example, the song "Glory Days" is about people from a small town remembering their youth, when they felt strong and full of hope. "Downbound Train" tells the story of a young man whose life falls apart after he loses his job.

original: Lewis would like to see the number of marine protected areas in the world increase from 3 per cent to 10 per cent in an attempt to reverse the damage caused by human activity such as overfishing, polluting and littering. During his expeditions, Lewis has witnessed this environmental destruction first-hand. He's swum over coral reefs bleached by the increase in water temperature, and observed underwater deserts beneath the shallow waters of the Red Sea, devoid of life and strewn with plastic. Pugh believes that nature can recover if it is given space to do so, but the clock is ticking. If we don't start looking after our seas, we may soon have an unsolvable problem on our hands.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Lewis wants to increase the number of protected areas in the world's oceans from 3% to 10%. He thinks this can help fix the damage caused by human activities like overfishing, pollution, and littering. Lewis has seen this damage himself during his underwater trips. He has swum over coral reefs that have turned white because of warmer water and seen empty, lifeless areas under the water in the Red Sea, filled with plastic. Lewis believes that nature can heal if we give it space, but time is running out. If we don't start taking care of our oceans, we may soon face a problem that we can't solve.
mistral-medium-3:
Lewis wants more protected areas in the ocean. Right now, only 3% of the ocean is protected, but he thinks it should be 10%. This could help fix the damage people have caused, like overfishing, pollution, and trash in the water.

During his trips, Lewis has seen this damage himself. He has swum over coral reefs that have turned white because the water is too warm. He has also seen empty areas under the Red Sea with no life, just plastic everywhere.

Lewis believes nature can heal if we give it a chance, but we don’t have much time. If we don’t start taking care of the ocean now, the problem might become too big to fix.
gemma-3-27b-it:
Lewis wants more areas in the ocean to be protected – he wants to increase this from 3% to 10% of the world’s seas. He hopes this will help to repair the damage that people are causing, such as catching too many fish, pollution, and dropping litter. Lewis has seen this damage himself during his travels. He has swum over coral reefs that have lost their colour because the water is getting warmer, and he has seen parts of the Red Sea with no life in them, just plastic. Lewis thinks nature can get better if we let it, but we don’t have much time left. If we don’t start protecting our seas, we will soon have a very serious problem that we can’t fix.

**Here's a little explanation of some words:**

* **Coral reefs:** These are like underwater cities built by tiny animals. They are very colourful and full of life.
* **Bleached:** When coral reefs lose their colour, it means they are not healthy. This often happens when the water gets too warm.
* **Pollution:** This means making the environment dirty, for example, by adding harmful chemicals or waste.

Pugh thinks that nature can heal if we give it enough space, but time is running out. If we do not start caring for our seas, we could soon face a problem that is very hard to solve.

original: Best-selling author Terrie Sharp knows how to tell a good story or two, having twice won the Olive Crime Writer Award. Born on the housing estate with the highest crime rate in Glasgow, she learned to keep quiet, stay out of trouble and how to open car doors with a knife. Luckily, she only used her knowledge to write her novels and she's not so quiet these days, appearing on popular daytime shows like Police Today and at writing conferences throughout the UK.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Terrie Sharp is a successful writer who knows how to tell exciting stories. She has won a prestigious award called the Olive Crime Writer Award twice. Terrie grew up in a tough neighborhood in Glasgow, which had a lot of crime. As a result, she learned to be careful and stay out of trouble. She even learned how to open car doors with a knife, but luckily she only uses this knowledge to write her books. Nowadays, Terrie is not shy and appears on popular TV shows like Police Today and attends writing conferences all over the UK.

original: Are things getting worse every day? Is progress an impossible goal? In Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at the big picture of human progress and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, freer and happier lives. The real problem, Pinker argues, is that the Enlightenment values of reason and science are under attack. When commentators and demagogues appeal to people's tribalism, fatalism and distrust, then we are in danger of causing irreparable damage to important institutions like democracy and world co-operation.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: Are things getting worse every day? Is it impossible to make the world a better place? In his book "Enlightenment Now", Steven Pinker looks at the overall situation of human progress and finds some positive news. People are now living longer, healthier, and happier lives, and they have more freedom. However, Pinker thinks there is a real problem. The ideas of the Enlightenment, such as using reason and science to make decisions, are being challenged. When some people try to make others think in a certain way by appealing to their emotions and prejudices, it can cause serious harm to important systems like democracy and international cooperation.
mistral-medium-3: Are things getting worse every day? Is progress impossible? In *Enlightenment Now*, Steven Pinker looks at human progress and finds good news. Are things getting worse, or are they actually improving? In his book, Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at how humans have progressed over time and says there is reason to be positive. People are living longer, healthier, more free and happier lives now than in the past. 

Pinker believes the main problem is that the ideas of the Enlightenment – using reason and science to understand the world – are being questioned. When leaders and public speakers encourage people to focus on their group identity, feel hopeless, and not trust others, it could seriously harm important things like democracy and international teamwork.
gpt-oss-120b:
Are things getting worse every day? Is progress impossible?  

In the book *Enlightenment Now*, Steven Pinker looks at the whole picture of human progress and finds good news. We now live longer, are healthier, have more freedom and are happier.  

Pinker says the real problem is that the ideas of the Enlightenment – mainly using reason (thinking logically) and science – are being attacked.  

When commentators and demagogues (people who try to gain power by using strong emotions and lies) appeal to people’s tribalism (strong loyalty to their own group), fatalism (the belief that nothing can change) and distrust, we risk causing serious, lasting damage to important institutions such as democracy and world cooperation.

When people who comment on news and political leaders try to make people think only about their own group, believe nothing can change, and not trust others, then we are in danger of seriously damaging important things like democracy and countries working together around the world.

original: In older horror films, when protagonists were in desperation, it was difficult or impossible for them to call for help or call the police. Mobile phones have made that situation a bit less believable now. What's the solution to maintain suspense? No phone coverage! If you're a hero in a horror film, it's almost certain that at a key moment, just when you absolutely need to call for help, you will not have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die just as you are making the call. Or both.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: In old horror movies, it was hard for the main characters to call for help when they were in trouble. Now, with mobile phones, this situation is less realistic. So, how do filmmakers keep the tension? They often show that there's no phone signal. If you're the hero in a horror movie, it's almost certain that when you really need to call for help, you won't have any signal. Or your phone will run out of battery just as you're making the call. Or maybe both things will happen.
mistral-medium-3: In old scary movies, when the main characters were in trouble, they couldn’t call for help or the police. It was hard or impossible. If you’re the hero in a horror film, you can be sure that at the worst moment—just when you really need to call for help—your phone won’t work. Maybe there’s no signal, or your battery dies right when you’re making the call. Or both things happen!

original: In the 1950s, Central American commercial banana growers were facing the death of their most lucrative product, the Gros Michel banana, known as Big Mike. And now it's happening again to Big Mike's successor – the Cavendish. With its easily transported, thick-skinned and sweet-tasting fruit, the Gros Michel banana plant dominated the plantations of Central America. United Fruit, the main grower and exporter in South America at the time, mass-produced its bananas in the most efficient way possible: it cloned shoots from the stems of plants instead of growing plants from seeds, and cultivated them in densely packed fields.
llama-3.3-70b-instruct: In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America had a big problem. Their most profitable banana, the Gros Michel, also known as Big Mike, was dying. Now, the same thing is happening to its replacement, the Cavendish. The Gros Michel banana was very popular because it was easy to transport, had a thick skin, and tasted sweet. It was the main banana grown on plantations in Central America. The biggest banana company at the time, United Fruit, grew bananas in a very efficient way. Instead of growing new plants from seeds, they took cuttings from the stems of existing plants and planted them close together in large fields. This method allowed them to produce a lot of bananas quickly.
mistral-medium-3:
In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America had a big problem. Their most popular banana, called the Gros Michel (or "Big Mike"), was dying. Now, the same thing is happening to the Cavendish banana, which replaced the Gros Michel.

The Gros Michel was very popular because it was easy to transport, had thick skin, and tasted sweet. It was grown on large farms in Central America. The main company growing and selling these bananas, United Fruit, used a special method to grow them quickly. Instead of planting seeds, they took small parts from the stems of banana plants and grew new plants from them. They also planted the bananas very close together to save space.
gemma-3-27b-it:
In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America had a problem. Their most popular banana, called ‘Big Mike’ (or Gros Michel), was dying. Now, the same thing is happening to the banana that replaced ‘Big Mike’ – the Cavendish banana. 

‘Big Mike’ was a great banana because it was easy to transport, had a thick skin, and tasted sweet. It grew well on farms in Central America. A company called United Fruit, which grew and sold most of the bananas at that time, found a quick way to grow them. Instead of using seeds, they took small parts of the banana plants and grew new plants from them. They planted these plants very close together in fields to grow as many bananas as possible.
gpt-oss-120b:
In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America were losing their most valuable banana, the Gros Michel (called “Big Mike”). The same problem is now happening to its replacement, the Cavendish.  

The Gros Michel was popular because it could be moved easily, it had thick skin, and it tasted sweet. It was the main banana grown on Central American farms.  

United Fruit, the biggest grower and exporter in South America at that time, made bananas in a very efficient way: instead of planting seeds, it copied (cloned) new shoots that grew from the stems of existing plants, and it grew them close together in tightly packed fields.
claude-sonnet-4: In the 1950s, banana companies in Central America had a big problem. Their most profitable banana, called the Gros Michel banana (also known as Big Mike), was dying. Now the same thing is happening again to the banana that replaced it – the Cavendish. The Gros Michel banana was perfect for business because it had thick skin that made it easy to transport, and it tasted very sweet. This type of banana was grown everywhere on the plantations of Central America. United Fruit was the biggest company that grew and sold bananas in South America at that time. They produced huge amounts of bananas in the cheapest way they could: they made copies of plants by taking shoots (new growth) from the stems of existing plants instead of growing new plants from seeds. They grew these bananas very close together in large fields.
qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America were losing their most profitable banana, the Gros Michel, also called Big Mike. Now, the same thing is happening to its replacement – the Cavendish banana. The Gros Michel was popular because its fruit was sweet, had thick skin, and was easy to transport. It grew widely on large farms in Central America. United Fruit, the main company growing and selling bananas in South America at the time, produced them very efficiently. Instead of growing plants from seeds, they used cuttings from banana plant stems – a method called cloning. They planted these close together in large fields.
